[[Larian Studios]], through [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroep]] | publisher = [[BBC]] and [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroep]] | engine = Meqon Game Dynamics | platforms = [[Personal computer|PC]] | released = 5 September 2007 (Trial Phase 1 - 1,000 participants){{cite web|title=BBC - MESSAGE BOARDS - CBBC - PLEASE READ - Important Information - Conversation |publisher=BBC |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/mbcbbc/F8140211?thread=4554868 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111113141/http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/mbcbbc/F8140211?thread=4554868 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-11-11 |accessdate=2008-03-07 }} (only available when logged into forums)
8 January 2008 (Trial Phase 2 10,000 participants){{cite web|title=BBC - MESSAGE BOARDS - CBBC - Trial Phase Two - New Info! - Conversation |publisher=BBC |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/mbcbbc/F8140211?thread=4935656 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121112091733/http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/mbcbbc/F8140211?thread=4935656 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-11-12 |accessdate=2008-03-07 }} (only available when logged into forums) 1 March 2008 (Final Version) | genre = [[Adventure game|First-person adventure]]
[[Educational game|Educational]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | designer = }} '''''Adventure Rock''''' (previously known as '''''CBBC World''''') was a virtual online world for children based on Ketnetkick,''Adventure Rock'' Credits, found within the game interface and created by the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] in association with [[Ketnet]], owned and operated by the [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroep]] (VRT), Flanders' public broadcaster.{{cite news| publisher= Lizzie Jackson| accessdate= 2008-03-06| date= 2007-11-30| url= http://lizziejackson.com/2007/11/30/adventure-rock/| title= Adventure Rock| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080228051343/http://lizziejackson.com/2007/11/30/adventure-rock/| archivedate= 28 February 2008| deadurl= yes| df= dmy-all}} The game was originally aimed at the Belgian market, but was redeveloped for a UK audience of children aged between 6–12 years old.{{cite news|publisher = Epicentre|accessdate = 2008-03-06|url=http://www.epicentre.co.uk/newsletter/|title =Epicentre Newsletter}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The emphasis on the system was on safety and responsibility, with no [[chatrooms]] or the financial aspects available in other online worlds such as [[Linden Lab]]'s ''[[Second Life]]''.{{cite news|publisher = Brisbane Times|accessdate = 2008-03-06|date=2007-10-09|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/news/technology/bbc-launches-virtual-world/2007/10/09/1191695864322.html|title =BBC Launches Virtual World| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080211215954/http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/news/technology/bbc-launches-virtual-world/2007/10/09/1191695864322.html| archivedate= 11 February 2008 | deadurl= no}} Controller of [[CBBC]] Richard Deverell said:{{cite news|publisher = BBC|accessdate = 2008-03-06|date=2007-01-23|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6290585.stm|title =BBC plans online children's world}} {{cquote| ''[Adventure Rock]'' is a good example of the way we need to go. The thing that interests me is that children are at the vanguard. And that is where we are taking Children's BBC. }} Adventure Rock was shut down in 2009 due to lack of popularity, updates and repairs. ==Gameplay== [[Image:AdventureRockScreenshot.jpg|thumb|left|Screenshot from open Beta Testing of Adventure Rock]] ''Adventure Rock'' consists of a large virtual world which players explore using customised avatars. They are accompanied by Cody, a floating robot who guides and helps the player. The game starts with a tutorial in which Cody teaches the player how to control the avatar. Following that, the player is 'dropped' onto Adventure Rock, and is free to explore. There are a number of continuous tasks to do, such as collecting the hundreds of cog-shaped tokens, or pages torn from a book, the purpose of which was still unknown at the time of the game's closure. In doing these, the player gains points. There are also a number of different 'studios', including an art studio, a music studio and an animation studio, in which the player can create their own animations etc. which can then be submitted to [[CBBC]]. There are a number of areas which were closed off, such as a [[roller coaster]]. Some of these were released over time but the game was taken down with many areas still locked. ===Story=== The game was based around a story narrated on the ''Adventure Rock'' website. The story section of the website states that:{{cite web | title = BBC - CBBC - Adventure Rock - The Story | publisher = BBC | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/adventurerock/thestory | accessdate = 2008-03-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080228103118/http://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/adventurerock/thestory| archivedate= 28 February 2008 | deadurl= no}} {{cquote| A short while ago a strange rift appeared on the CBBC website leading to an unknown world. A decision was made to send in two of our hosts to study the strange world. This is the report they sent back from a world that holds more questions than answers... }} The website then continues in the style of a blog written by the hosts sent to explore the world, detailing various discoveries made by the hosts. The blog goes on to detail how the hosts are returning to the studio to examine the pages found, and that they need more help, and will hence be sending in CBBC users to investigate further. ==Research== ''Adventure Rock'' was the subject of a year-long joint research project between [[CBBC]] and the [[University of Westminster]], funded by BBC Future Media and Technology, and the [[Arts and Humanities Research Council]] which began in July 2007, and aims to look at how children engage with virtual worlds.{{cite web | title = AHRC/BBC Knowledge Exchange Programme: Summary of Awards 2007 | publisher = AHRC | url = http://www.ahrc.ac.uk/images/ahrc_bbc_summary_awards.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2008-03-06| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071022055253/http://www.ahrc.ac.uk/images/ahrc_bbc_summary_awards.pdf| archivedate = October 22, 2007}} It is the first time the BBC has run a structured commissioning round calling for research in partnership with academia. ''Adventure Rock'' will be studied from both an audience and producer’s point of view, with the hope of finding out how children create imaginary places and spaces in the real world, how children wish ''Adventure Rock'' to develop, how producers should adapt the way they engage with children around the ''Adventure Rock'' ‘brand’ (which includes the service, website, message boards etc.) and what parents think of ''Adventure Rock'' (specifically whether the service changes their perception of ''Adventure Rock'' and/or virtual worlds in general). The project will also study why the BBC chose to make ''Adventure Rock'' a closed world where users' avatars cannot meet or communicate, and what children think of this.{{cite web| title = Audience and producer engagement with immersive worlds (Case study: ''Adventure Rock'')| publisher = Artlab| url = http://www.artlab.org.uk/ahrc-bbc-project.htm| accessdate = 2008-03-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080406070456/http://www.artlab.org.uk/ahrc-bbc-project.htm| archivedate= 6 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} Research workshops have already taken place in December 2007 and January 2008, with 75 participants aged 7–11 years, in five mixed socio-economic and ethnic groups located in Scotland, Wales, N Ireland, and England. At this workshop the children were asked to talk about imaginary spaces and places, and suggest what they would like to see in a virtual world. Six weeks later, during which the children were asked to explore ''Adventure Rock'', a second workshop was held in which the children made creative suggestions about what they would add or remove from this virtual place. Parents were asked to complete a questionnaire regarding their feelings about their children participating in this virtual world. In addition, a researcher spent time observing the producers and hosts of CBBC, completing a detailed research diary, which was then used to note congruencies and disparities between producers' expectations and children's own responses. The findings have been presented at the Conference on Virtual Worlds for Children, on 23 May 2008. ==Criticism== ''Adventure Rock'' received many complaints from its users. For example, on the [http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/mbcbbc/NF19369152 CBBC Games Messageboards], many have stated that they have problems downloading, opening or playing the game. Lack of support for these led to many players abandoning the game and to its eventual shutdown. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/adventurerock/ ''Adventure Rock'' Homepage] *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/adventurerock/hints/faq.shtml ''Adventure Rock'' FAQs] [[Category:2008 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Fantasy video games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Belgium]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Akai Ito |image = Akai Ito.jpg |developer = [[Success Corporation]] |publisher = [[Success Corporation]], Hamster |designer = Hal |released = '''PlayStation 2'''{{vgrelease|JP|October 21, 2004}}{{vgrelease|JP|October 27, 2005 (SuperLite 2000 Series)}}'''PlayStation Network'''{{vgrelease|JP|October 16, 2013}} |genre = [[Visual novel]], [[adventure game|adventure]], [[Horror fiction|horror]], [[Yuri (genre)|yuri]]<ref name="hime-8x">{{cite journal |last=Morishima |first=Akiko |date=April 2007 |title=YurixYuri Kenbunroku |journal=[[Comic Yuri Hime]] |issue=8 |asin=B000PAAJN8 |language=Japanese}}</ref> |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 2]] |caption = |alt = }} {{nihongo|'''''Akai Ito'''''|アカイイト||lit. "Red Thread"}} is a Japanese horror [[adventure game]] by [[Success Corporation]], released exclusively for the PlayStation 2 in Japan on October 21, 2004. A reduced price "popular edition," included in developer and publisher [[Success (company)|SUCCESS]]' ''SuperLite 2000 Series'', was released on October 27, 2005. The title refers to the mythical [[red string of fate]]. Akai Ito has not been officially released outside Japan, but there has been a fan effort to translate it, similar to the popular [[dōjin]] game ''[[Tsukihime]]''.
==Story== To arrange the inheritance because of the loss of her mother, Kei Hatō heads for her father's house in Hemizuka. In the train on the way there, Kei has a mysterious dream of a huge tree and a woman who seems to be lost in sadness. In Hemizuka, Kei learns the secret concealed in her own blood through various meeting with an [[Oni (folklore)|Oni]] Slayer, a friend of her late mother, a young girl accompanied by a white fox, and even the mysterious girl from her dreams. Throughout the story Kei is antagonized by the twin oni Nozomi and Mikage. Akai Ito's story varies greatly based upon the player's decisions, which not only affect the flow of the story but also the ending the player receives (several of which suggest romantic feelings among the female characters).
==Character== [[Image:Akai ito light novel.jpg|thumb|''Akai Ito'''s main characters, as depicted in the novel adaptation.]] *{{nihongo|'''Kei Hatō'''|羽藤桂}} (CV: [[Miyu Matsuki]]) The main character of the story, Kei is a rather careless person, which is quite ironic considering her favorite phrase is "always be prepared". *{{nihongo|'''Yumei'''|ユメイ}} (CV: [[Yūko Minaguchi]]) The mysterious girl from Kei's dreams. *{{nihongo|'''Uzuki Senba '''|千羽烏月}} (CV: [[Akeno Watanabe]]) The Oni Slayer Kei meets at the train station, her sword is the very bane of the oni. *{{nihongo|'''Tsuzura Wakasugi'''|若杉葛}} (CV: [[Rie Kugimiya]]) A girl half Kei's age, accompanied by a white fox. Kei meets her in her father's now abandoned house. *{{nihongo|'''Sakuya Asama'''|浅間サクヤ}} (CV: [[Asami Sanada]]) A friend of Kei's deceased mother. She goes by the nickname "West". *{{nihongo|'''Nozomi , Mikage'''|ノゾミ・ミカゲ}} (CV: [[Megumi Kobayashi]]) Twin oni and the antagonists of the story. *{{nihongo|'''Kei'''|ケイ}} (CV: [[Kazutaka Ishii]]) A mysterious male, later known as Kei's brother called Hakuka. *{{nihongo|'''Mayumi Hatō'''|羽藤真弓}} (CV: [[Nana Furuhara]]) *{{nihongo|'''Yōko Nara'''|奈良陽子}} (CV: [[Mamiko Noto]]) *{{nihongo|'''Rin Tōgo'''|東郷凛}} (CV: [[Miyuki Sawashiro]])
==Staff== *Character design / Original picture : HAL *Script : Tomoyuki Fumotogawa *Music : MANYO (Little Wing) *Background : [[J.C.Staff]]
==Music== *Opening theme song 『 ''Mawaru Sekai de'' (廻る世界で) 』 by [[Haruka Shimotsuki]] / [[Riya]] *Ending theme song 『 ''Tabiji no Hate'' (旅路の果て) 』 by [[Haruka Shimotsuki]] / [[Riya]]
==Adaptations==
===Manga=== Akai Ito has also received several manga adaptations: a one-shot by Muttri Moony published in the July 2004 issue of Yuri Shimai, by the name "Swear"; and a short manga published in the May and June 2007 issues of Monthly [[Comic Rush]]. A special [[anthology]] was created for a limited edition version Akai Ito, the anthology featured various stories from different artists.
===Web Novel=== A free web novel of Akai Ito was released on [[Success (company)|Success]]' official Akai Ito website,<ref name="web novel">[http://www.success-corp.co.jp/software/ps2/akaiito/novel/index_wn.htm Akai Ito web novel] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501061520/http://www.success-corp.co.jp/software/ps2/akaiito/novel/index_wn.htm |date=2009-05-01 }}, Akai Ito's web novel.</ref> it follows one of the storylines accessible when playing the video game.
===Drama CD=== One [[drama CD]] has been released. It was first released as a Limited Edition version in October 2005 and later a regular version was released on December 26, 2006.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.success-corp.co.jp/software/ps2/akaiito/info.html | title=アカイイトドラマCD「京洛降魔」（通常版）|publisher=[[Success (company)|Success]] | accessdate=August 12, 2009 | language=Japanese}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=June 2013}} [[File:Association of American Weather Observers logo.jpg|thumb|AAWO logo created in 2006 and used until 2010]]
The '''Association of American Weather Observers''' was a group of amateur weather observers from around the United States. Their aim was to educate the public on weather awareness and to simply share stories among themselves on recent extreme weather that they viewed at their location.
The AAWO originally began in 1983 in [[Westwood, New Jersey]] as a group of weather enthusiasts came together in October of that year to create the organization. The AAWO disbanded in 1993 due to conflicts of interests. In 2005, a new weather [[organization]] under the same name was created to try to bring back what once existed within the old AAWO. Unlike the old [[organization]], the new AAWO has yet to create a [[President]] and [[Board of directors]]. The AAWO that was established in 1983 and ended in 1993 is in no way affiliated with nor associated with the later organization that was established in 2005. However, some who were prominent members of the first AAWO had shown support for the new surge in bringing back the organization.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}
== Education, communication, cooperation== When the AAWO began in 1983, their [[motto]] was "Education, Communication, Cooperation" and opened the door for amateur weather observers from all over the United States to communicate with each other via the American Weather Observer newspaper publication. Before the AAWO there was no nationally recognized organization for the amateur weather hobbyist to share stories and observational data among each other. The group not only had individual memberships, but also had a lengthy list of [[Network affiliate|affiliate]] organizations that were mostly local or regional groups from within the U.S.. The restart of the AAWO in 2005 had the same basic plans as the old group had in 1983. One of the differences between the group created in 1983 versus 2005 is, in 2005, the American Weather Observer publication was owned and operated by the AAWO, where the publication created in 1984 was a separate entity owned by the Belvidere Republican in [[Belvidere, Illinois]], and only affiliated themselves with the AAWO organization created in 1983 as the newspapers official network.
== History == [[Image:Aawo old.JPG|thumb|left|AAWO logo created in 1983 and used until 1993]]
*1983: The '''Association of American Weather Observers''' (AAWO) was created. *1984: The AAWO began a monthly publication, in conjunction with the Belvidere Republican in [[Belvidere, Illinois]], in the format of a newspaper called the American Weather Observer (AWO). Weather-related stories and weather observations recorded by the membership would be the major content of the [[newspaper]]. *1993: The American Weather Observer (monthly publication of the AAWO) announced its separation from the AAWO in their June issue and became a "stand-alone" publication. Meanwhile, the board members of the AAWO, in an official letter to their affiliate organizations, announced the ending of the AAWO. *2005: The AAWO, under a new format, made a return on September 20 in the form of a web site https://web.archive.org/web/20060614230631/http://www.aawo.net/ *2006: The AAWO begins a newsletter style publication under the same name used by the old AAWO, The American Weather Observer, in a periodic newsletter style format. *2010: On June 16, the Association of American Weather Observers ended operations.

==Publications== The '''''American Weather Observer''''' was a newsletter publication presented by the Association of American Weather Observers(AAWO).
Each issue had articles pertaining to significant weather events and was also a communications forum for the AAWO membership. The newsletter was mailed out in paperback format and was available on line at their web site in [[Adobe Acrobat]] format.

{{Infobox person | name = Bessie Sue Loo | image = Bessie Loo.jpg | alt = | caption = Beulah Quo and Bessie Loo | birth_name = Bessie Sue | birth_date = {{Birth date|1902|12|30}} | birth_place = Hanford, California | death_date = {{Death date and age|1998|10|28|1902|12|30}} | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = actress, agent | years_active = | known_for = Bessie Loo Talent Agency | spouse = Richard Loo
(1929–1960 divorce) | notable_works = }} '''Bessie Loo''' (December 30, 1902 – October 28, 1998) was an American actress, casting director, and talent agent. She owned the Bessie Loo Talent Agency for over 40 years, and represented many of the Asian-American actors in 20th-century Hollywood. ==Early life == Loo was born as Bessie Sue in [[Hanford, California]]. Loo's father, Sue Chung Kee, immigrated to Hanford from China in 1886, and operated a general store there; Loo's mother was born in San Francisco.Susie Ling, [http://imdiversity.com/villages/asian/bessie-loo-delbert-wong-and-richard-wing-of-hanford-cas-china-alley/ "Bessie Loo, Delbert Wong, and Richard Wing of Hanford, CA's China Alley"] IMDiversity (October 20, 2012).“Sue Chung Kee Store, Hanford,” San Joaquin Valley & Sierra Foothill Photo Heritage, accessed September 4, 2015, http://photoheritage.sjvls.org/document/652. The Sue family lived above their store. == Education == Loo attended the [[University of California at Los Angeles]], and graduated from [[San Francisco State University|San Francisco Teachers College]] in 1928.Jack Ong, [http://www.jackong.com/bessie.html "From Hanford to Hollywood: Remembering Bessie Loo"] ''Gum Saan Journal'' (2007), published by the Chinese Historical Society of Southern California. ==Career== As an actress of Chinese descent, Loo's acting career started in 1930s. Loo mostly played small parts. Loo appeared in ''[[The Good Earth (film)|The Good Earth]]'' (1937), and was a maid in ''[[Mr. Wong in Chinatown]]'' (1939); her husband [[Richard Loo]] was also in the cast of both films. She began working with [[Central Casting]] during the making of ''The Good Earth'', when her language skills proved useful with the many Chinese-speaking extras. During the opening of [[World War II]], Loo started The Bessie Loo Talent Agency, with offices on [[Sunset Boulevard]] in Los Angeles, California. Loo represented Asian-American actors in the film industry,Patrick McNulty, [http://search.proquest.com/hnplatimes/docview/167350770/F92D3FC42EA444F0PQ/9 "Actress's Odd Career: Locating Orientals"] ''Los Angeles Times'' (August 31, 1958): D3. including [[Jack Ong]], [[Keye Luke]], [[Robert Ito]], [[Beulah Quo]], [[James Hong]], [[Soon-Tek Oh]], [[Mako Iwamatsu]], [[Joan Chen]], [[Lisa Lu]], and Guy Lee (who eventually took over the agency when Bessie Loo retired). All the founding members of the [[East West Players]] were represented by Bessie Loo.[http://emmytvlegends.org/interviews/people/james-hong# "Actor James Hong on his agent Bessie Loo informing him he'd been cast on ''Marco Polo''"] Archives of American Television, interview conducted April 27, 2010.William Wong, [http://www.aiisf.org/stories-by-author/607-chen-joan "Immigrant Voices: Actress, Director, and Immigrant"] Angel Island Immigration Station Foundation.Wallace Wyss, [http://search.proquest.com/news/docview/371356319/8EB7B443F90A4B54PQ/2 "Lee Deals in Asian Talent"] ''Asian Week'' (December 25, 1987): 16.Lloyd Shearer, [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3156966/bessie_loo_1961_page_1_of_2/ "Hollywood Comes to Bessie Loo for Oriental Beauties"] ''Long Beach Independent Press-Telegram'' (January 15, 1961): 78-79. via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} Bessie Loo served as president of the China Society of Southern California,China Society of Southern California, [http://digitallibrary.usc.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15799coll32/id/55/rec/4 Recognition of Bessie Loo] (February 17, 1977). and of the Los Angeles Chinese Women's Club.Jenny Cho, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5KzsbYLLzfAC&lpg=PA2 ''Chinatown in Los Angeles''] (Arcade Publishing 2009): cover photo, 2. {{ISBN|9780738569567}} She was also an appointed member of the California State Economic Development Commission, and a member of the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]. In 1978 her achievements were honored at a dinner of the [[Chinese Historical Society of Southern California]], and in 1982 her friend and client James Hong organized an event with the Association of Asian Pacific American Artists (AAPAA) called "An Affair with Bessie," to celebrate her career. Just weeks before she died, she was honored for "Excellence in Entertainment" by the [[Chinese American Museum]] of Los Angeles, at their annual Historymakers Awards Banquet.[http://camla.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Honorees-Over-the-Years.pdf CAMLA Honorees over the Years] Chinese American Museum of Los Angeles. ==Personal life== Loo married actor Richard Loo in 1929; they had twin daughters together, Beverly and Angela, born in 1931.[https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/obituaries/richard-loo-actor-5-decades.html "Richard Loo, Actor 5 Decades"] ''New York Times'' (November 22, 1983). In 1998, Loo died. She was 95 years old. Archival footage of Loo, and a brief discussion of her work, was featured in the [[Arthur Dong]] documentary ''[[Hollywood Chinese]]'' (2007). ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://digitallibrary.usc.edu/cdm/singleitem/collection/p15799coll126/id/15569/rec/11 A photograph of Bessie Sue in 1920], from the University of Southern California Libraries. *{{IMDb name|0519601}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loo, Bessie}} [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1998 deaths]] [[Category:Actresses from California]] [[Category:People from Hanford, California]] [[Category:American actresses of Chinese descent]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles alumni]] [[Category:San Francisco State University alumni]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:Talent agents]]

[[Dish Network]] (2011-) | homepage = {{URL|http://blockbuster.com/}} }} '''Blockbuster LLC''', formerly '''Blockbuster Entertainment, Inc.''', and also known as '''Blockbuster Video'''{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/03/21/blockbuster-bankruptcy-economics-opinions-columnists-john-tamny.html|title=What Blockbuster Video Can Teach Us About Economics|last=Tamny|first=John|date=March 22, 2010|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=April 24, 2017}} or simply '''Blockbuster''', is an American-based provider of home movie and video game rental services through [[video rental shop]]s, [[DVD-by-mail]], [[streaming media|streaming]], [[video on demand]], and cinema theater.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/news/ni0228635/|title=Blockbuster opening Mexico multiplex|work=IMDb}} Blockbuster became internationally known throughout the 1990s. At its peak in 2004, Blockbuster employed 84,300 people worldwide, including about 58,500 in the United States and about 25,800 in other countries, and had 9,094 stores in total, with more than 4,500 of these in the US.{{cite web|title=The Sad End Of Blockbuster Video: The Onetime $5 Billion Company Is Being Liquidated As Competition From Online Giants Netflix And Hulu Prove All Too Much For The Iconic Brand|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/sad-end-blockbuster-video-onetime-5-billion-company-being-liquidated-competition-1496962|website=International Business Times|date=5 December 2013}}{{cite news|title=Other Retailers Find Ex-Blockbuster Stores Just Right|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/09/business/09blockbuster.html|work=The New York Times|first=Stephanie|last=Clifford|date=April 8, 2011}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1085734/000119312505063510/d10k.htm|title=Form 10-K|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2017-06-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/6711543/ns/business-us_business/t/blockbuster-end-late-fees/#.WppwOmeWycw|title=Blockbuster to end late fees in 2005|date=December 14, 2004|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} Competition from the [[Netflix]] mail-order service, [[Redbox]] automated kiosks, and [[video on demand]] services were major factors in Blockbuster's eventual demise. Blockbuster began to lose significant revenue during the 2000s, and in 2010, the company filed for bankruptcy protection.{{cite web|title=Blockbuster LLC Chapter 11 Petition|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/PXDYCPY/Blockbuster_Inc.__nysbke-10-14997__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|publisher=PacerMonitor|accessdate=9 May 2016}}{{cite press release |title=Blockbuster Reaches Agreement on Plan to Recapitalize Balance Sheet and Substantially Reduce its Indebtedness |publisher=Blockbuster |date=September 23, 2010 |url= http://investor.blockbuster.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=99383&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1474126 |accessdate=September 23, 2010}} The following year, its remaining 1,700 stores were bought by satellite television provider [[Dish Network]].{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/apr/07/business/la-fi-ct-dish-blockbuster-20110407 |title=Dish Network wins bidding for assets of bankrupt Blockbuster |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate= May 2, 2011 |first=Ben |last=Fritz |date=April 7, 2011}}{{cite web|title=DISH Network Completes Acquisition of Blockbuster Assets|url=http://about.dish.com/press-release/financial/dish-network-completes-acquisition-blockbuster-assets|date=April 26, 2011|publisher=DishNetwork.MediaRoom.com|accessdate=June 16, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717202917/http://about.dish.com/press-release/financial/dish-network-completes-acquisition-blockbuster-assets|archive-date=July 17, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} While the Blockbuster brand has mostly been retired, Dish maintained a small number of Blockbuster franchise agreements, which allowed some stores to remain open, eventually leaving just one U.S. store open in [[Bend, Oregon]],{{cite web|first=Annie|last=Zak|publisher=[[Anchorage Daily News]]|url=https://www.adn.com/business-economy/2018/07/12/the-last-two-blockbuster-stores-in-alaska-are-set-to-close/|title=Alaska's last 2 Blockbuster stores are closing, leaving just one in the U.S.|date=July 12, 2018|access-date=August 29, 2018}} and a few in Australia. In the [[Nordic countries]], the brand rights are now held by [[TDC A/S]], and Blockbuster continues as a [[video on demand]] service. ==History== ===1985–1997: David Cook era=== Blockbuster's early beginnings can be traced back to another company, Cook Data Services, that was founded by David Cook in 1978.{{cite news|work=CNN Money|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2003/07/01/347314/index.htm|title=He Began Blockbuster. So What? David Cook created a household name, but he refuses to become one.|date=July 1, 2003|first=Joshua|last=Hyatt|accessdate=January 23, 2014}}{{cite web|work=Reference for Business|title=Blockbuster Inc. - Company Profile, Information, Business Description, History, Background Information on Blockbuster Inc.|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/93/Blockbuster-Inc.html|accessdate=January 1, 2017}} The company's primary goal was to supply software services to the oil and gas industries throughout [[Texas]], but it was not very successful. Sandy Cook, David's wife, wanted to get into the video business, and her husband would soon study the industry and future prospects.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=UZEpBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT77&dq=Blockbuster+mid-80s,+Sandy+Cook+TV+VCR&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-i47j4YXaAhVEFywKHT3cDBUQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Blockbuster+mid-80s,+Sandy+Cook+TV+VCR&f=false|title=Dear Investor, What the HELL are You Doing?: Smart and Easy Ways to Fix the Mistakes You Make With Your Money|first=Ken|last=Weber|date=January 6, 2015|publisher=Greenleaf Book Group|accessdate=July 13, 2018|via=Google Books}} Using profit he made from the sale of David P. Cook & Associates, the subsidiary of his company, he decided to buy into a video store franchise in Dallas known as Video Works. When Video Works would not allow him to decorate the interior of his store with a blue-and-yellow design, he departed the franchise and opened the first Blockbuster Video in 1985.{{cite web|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-magazine/2017/august/premiere-video-dallas-close-the-last-video-store/|title=Film Lovers Mourn Mockingbird Staple Premiere Video|website=D Magazine|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/710979/0000950144-94-000803.txt|title=SEC 10-K, 1999|last=|first=|date=March 24, 2000|website=SEC|access-date=June 7, 2017}} When he realized the potential in video rentals, Cook abandoned the oil industry and renamed his company Blockbuster Entertainment.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestreet.com/story/10867574/1/the-rise-and-fall-of-blockbuster-the-long-rewinding-road.html|title=Blockbuster's Rise and Fall: The Long, Rewinding Road|first=Jeanine|last=Poggi|date=September 23, 2010|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} The first Blockbuster store opened October 19, 1985, in [[Dallas]], Texas, with an inventory of 8,000 VHS and 2,000 Beta tapes.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/chapter/chap0009.htm |title=The Making of a Blockbuster |work=Bloomberg Businessweek |accessdate=November 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101113051837/http://www.businessweek.com/chapter/chap0009.htm |archivedate=November 13, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/first-blockbuster-store-opens|title=1985: First Blockbuster Store Opens|publisher=The History Channel|accessdate=May 24, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=NiQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=Blockbuster+Video+Inc.+8,000+VHS+2,000+Beta+tapes&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSq-Wi64XaAhUGMJoKHQuRB5wQ6AEIKzAA#v=onepage&q=Blockbuster+Video+Inc.+8,000+VHS+2,000+Beta+tapes&f=false|title=Billboard|first=Nielsen Business Media|last=Inc|date=October 19, 1985|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|accessdate=July 13, 2018|via=Google Books}} Cook's experience with managing huge databases proved helpful in driving innovation within the industry. Following early success from the company's first stores, Cook built a $6-million warehouse in [[Garland, Texas]], to help sustain and support future growth that allowed new stores to open quickly. Blockbuster would often custom-tailor a store's inventory to its neighborhood, based on local demographics. In 1987, the company won a court case against [[Nintendo]], which paved the way for video game rental.{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=1&cId=3146206 |title=History of Videogame Lawsuits from |publisher=1UP.com |accessdate=June 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017051248/http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=1&cId=3146206 |archivedate=October 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Also that year, [[Waste Management, Inc|Waste Management]] co-founder [[Wayne Huizenga]], who originally had reservations about entering the video rental industry, agreed to acquire several Blockbuster stores.{{cite book|last=DeGeorge|first=Gail|title=The Making of a Blockbuster |year=1997 |publisher= Wiley|location=New York|isbn=0-471-15903-4|page=32}} At that point the number of stores counted 19, and attracted Huizenga's associate John Melk's attention due to its efficiency, family-friendly image and business model, and convinced Huizenga to have a look at it. Huizenga and Melk utilized techniques from their waste business and [[Ray Kroc]]'s model of expansion to rapidly expand Blockbuster, and soon they were opening a new store every 24 hours.{{cite book|last=DeGeorge|first=Gail|title=The Making of a Blockbuster |year=1995|publisher=Wiley|location=Prologue|isbn=0-471-15903-4}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=XKiGgl36bkgC&pg=PA200&dq=In+1987+John+J.+Melk,+Waste+Management&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzzMX104rZAhXHliwKHTyUDQoQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=In+1987+John+J.+Melk,+Waste+Management&f=false|title=American Inventors, Entrepreneurs, and Business Visionaries|first=Charles W.|last=Carey|date=May 14, 2014|publisher=Infobase Publishing|accessdate=July 13, 2018|via=Google Books}} They took over many of the existing Blockbuster franchise stores as well, and Huizenga even spent much of the late 1980s acquiring several of Blockbuster's rivals, including Major Video. [[File:2008-09-24 Blockbuster in Durham.jpg|thumb|right|A Blockbuster store in [[Durham, North Carolina]]]] In 1990, Blockbuster bought mid-Atlantic rival [[Erol Onaran|Erol's]] which had more than 250 stores.{{Cite news| url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1990-11-20/news/1990324060_1_blockbuster-erol-video-chain|title= Blockbuster agrees to buy Erol's chain Curran examining antitrust concerns|author= David Conn|publisher= [[The Baltimore Sun]] |date = November 20, 1990}} In 1992, Blockbuster acquired the Sound Warehouse and Music Plus music retail chains and created Blockbuster Music.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/20/business/company-news-blockbuster-agrees-to-buy-music-store-chain.html |title=Blockbuster Agrees to Buy Music Store Chain |first=Eben |last=Shapiro |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 20, 1992}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-09-10/local/me-33692_1_video-business |title=Store Wars : Retailing: A busy intersection has become the battleground for three giant music and video outlets. And just up the street, a specialty store is trying to carve out a niche. |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 10, 1993 |first=Ted |last=Johnson}} In October 1993, Blockbuster took [[controlling interest]] in [[Spelling Television|Spelling Entertainment Group]], a media company run by television producer [[Aaron Spelling]].[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SPELLING+ENTERTAINMENT+COMPLETES+SALE+OF+SHARES+TO+BLOCKBUSTER-a014212557 Spelling Entertainment Completes Sale of Shares to Blockbuster] thefreelibrary.com, Retrieved on May 27, 2013 Blockbuster purchased Super Club Retail Entertainment Corp. on November 22, 1993 from [[Philips |Philips Electronics, N.V.]] for 5.2 million shares of Blockbuster stock. This brought approximately 270 [[Record Bar]], Tracks, Turtles and Rhythm and Views music stores and approximately 160 video retail superstores into the corporation.{{cite web |title=Blockbuster Completes Super Club Acquisition |work=Orlando Sentinel |date=23 November 1993 |accessdate=6 October 2018 |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1993-11-23/business/9311230677_1_acquisition-blockbuster-retail-entertainment}} It also owned 35% of [[Republic Pictures]]; that company merged with Spelling in April 1994."Orlando Sentinel" [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-04-28/business/9404280996_1_republic-pictures-spelling-acquisition-of-republic Blockbuster's Spelling Finishes Buying Republic] OrlandoSentinel.com, Retrieved on May 27, 2013 Blockbuster became a multibillion-dollar company, but Huizenga was worried about how new technology could threaten their business, such as [[video on demand]] and the growth of cable television. In 1991, just three days after Time Warner had announced they would upgrade their cable system, Blockbuster's shares dropped more than 10 percent.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/magazine/entrepreneurs-wayne-huizenga-s-growth-complex.html|title=ENTREPRENEURS; WAYNE HUIZENGA'S GROWTH COMPLEX|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In 1993 he made an attempt to expand into other areas by investing in [[Viacom (original)|Viacom]].{{cite news|last=Sheridan|first=Mary Beth|title=Viacom-Blockbuster merges colorful moguls|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vDkfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ms8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4947,3465320 |accessdate= February 10, 2012|newspaper=[[Spartanburg Herald Journal]]|date=January 10, 1994 |agency= Associated Press}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/30/business/the-media-business-viacom-gets-help-from-blockbuster.html|title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Viacom Gets Help From Blockbuster|first=Geraldine|last=Fabrikant|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} Huizenga also considered buying a cable company, but this was unknown territory for Blockbuster and he decided not to take the risk. He also had the idea of a 2,500-acre Blockbuster sports and amusement park in Florida, something Blockbuster was still considering as late as August 1994.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/08/21/republic-of-huizenga-carved-out-of-florida-for-games/afb63fa7-a0cf-4de3-a3ab-dc270c2dcc5a/|title=REPUBLIC OF HUIZENGA CARVED OUT OF FLORIDA FOR GAMES|first=William|last=Booth|date=August 21, 1994|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} Unable to come up with a proper solution about how to face the growing threats to the traditional videostore, he made the decision to sell Blockbuster to Viacom and pull out.{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2022624-6,00.html|title=How Blockbuster Failed at Failing|first=Stephen|last=Gandel|date=October 17, 2010|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018|via=content.time.com}} Viacom acquired Blockbuster in 1994 for $8.4 billion to help finance its bid for [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] in the bidding war with QVC Network Inc.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-02-16/business/1994047156_1_viacom-qvc-redstone|title=Viacom captures Paramount|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/viacom-plans-blockbuster-split/|title=Viacom Plans Blockbuster Split|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} Blockbuster's stock trade had been dropping steadily the months before the merger, with a small rise after the deal was announced,{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-02-16/business/1994047156_1_viacom-qvc-redstone/2|title=Viacom captures Paramount|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} and three years later, in 1997, it's worth was estimated to just $4.6 billion.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/1997-05-04/viacoms-headache-its-a-blockbuster|title=Viacom's Headache: It's A Blockbuster|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} The Blockbuster Block Party concept was test-marketed in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]] and [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] in 1994. It was an "entertainment complex" aimed at adults, containing eight themed areas housing a restaurant, games, laser tag arena, and motion simulator rides, and was housed in a windowless building the size of a city block.{{cite news | url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19941219&id=mJgaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Fi0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6486,4788762 | title=This block party is for adults only: Blockbuster opens 1st indoor center | agency=Associated Press | accessdate=May 26, 2012}} During the 1990s, Blockbuster expanded in the United Kingdom, purchasing that country's Ritz Video chain. The stores were rebranded to Blockbuster, making it the number one UK rental chain.{{Cite news| url =http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2507142/Blockbuster-shut-quarter-UK-video-game-rental-stores-axe-450-jobs-going-administration.html|title= Blockbuster to shut a quarter of its UK video and game rental stores and axe 450 jobs after going into administration|author=Dan Bloom |publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |date = November 14, 2013 }} In 1996, the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation was renamed Blockbuster Entertainment Inc.{{cite web|url=http://blockbuster.com/ |title=Blockbuster's Entertainment Store! |work=website home page |date=December 24, 1996 |publisher=[[Wayback Machine]] |accessdate=November 7, 2013 |quote=Blockbuster name, design and related marks are trademarks of Blockbuster Entertainment Inc. © 1987, 1996 Blockbuster Entertainment Inc. All Rights Reserved. Developed by Blockbuster Technology – Online Group and Viacom Interactive Services. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025054228/http://www.blockbuster.com/ |archivedate=October 25, 2013 }} and the retail stores, then called Blockbuster Video, were renamed Blockbuster. The logo changed slightly, but retained the [[International Typeface Corporation|ITC Machine]] font.{{cite web |url= https://fontsinuse.com/uses/6800/blockbuster-identity |title= Blockbuster Identity - Fonts In Use |accessdate= December 26, 2016}} In November 1996 Blockbuster confirmed that it was moving its headquarters from [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] to the [[Renaissance Tower (Dallas)|Renaissance Tower]] in [[downtown Dallas]]."[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ST&s_site=dfw&p_multi=ST&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF90BCC96B3AB5&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Blockbuster sets meeting on move Video rental chain preparing possible relocation to Dallas]". ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]''. November 1, 1996. 1 Business. Retrieved December 18, 2009. Most of the workers at the Florida headquarters did not want to relocate, so Blockbuster planned to hire around 500 to 600 new employees for its Dallas headquarters. The company had offered various relocation packages to all of its Fort Lauderdale staff.Kirkpatrick, John. "[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DM&p_theme=dm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0ED3D8F8AA0E495C&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Blockbuster to hire hundreds in Dallas office. Two-thirds of Florida workers not moving with headquarters]". ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]''. March 17, 1997. Retrieved December 18, 2009. ===1997–2007: John Antioco era=== In 1998, Blockbuster created [[DEJ Productions]], which acquired 225 films primarily to provide exclusive content to its Blockbuster stores prior to being sold off to [[First Look Studios]] in 2005.Hettrick, Scott. DEJ Deal to First Look. Variety. November 5, 2005. During that same year, Blockbuster bought the Irish video rental store [[Xtra-vision]], with over 200 stores in Ireland and the UK. In 2009, Blockbuster sold off its Irish operations to Birchall Investments, with the few Xtra-vision stores in the UK being rebranded as Blockbuster. In 1998, when DVDs were emerging as the new video medium, [[Warner Bros.]] offered Antioco an exclusive rental deal. Blockbuster would have rights to rent new DVD releases for a period of time before they went on sale to the general public. The studio would receive 40% of rental revenues in return, which was the same deal already in place for VHS rentals. Blockbuster turned the offer down, and the studio responded by lowering their DVD wholesale price in order to compete with the rental industry. [[Walmart]] seized the opportunity and in a few years surpassed Blockbuster as the studios' single largest source of revenue. Other mass retailers soon followed suit. Many began selling DVDs below wholesale price in hopes of selling more items with better profit margins as a result of the additional foot traffic in their stores. Unable to match prices, Blockbuster's business model was severely impacted.{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/the_hollywood_economist/2006/01/hollywoods_new_zombie.html|title=Hollywood's New Zombie: The last days of Blockbuster.|last=Epstein|first=Edward Jay|date=January 9, 2006|publisher=Slate|accessdate=March 27, 2018}} In late 1998, Blockbuster launched a loyalty program called Blockbuster Rewards, where customers could earn free rentals and received an older title, called Blockbuster Favorites, rental free each month. After the 1998 test launch, the chain went nationwide with the program in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/blockbuster-loyalty-put-test-37266/|title=Blockbuster Loyalty Put To Test|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In August the same year, Viacom sold the Blockbuster Music chain to Wherehouse Entertainment, which was subsequently purchased by [[Trans World Entertainment]] in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.stereophile.com/news/10237/ |title=Wherehouse Buys Blockbuster Music for $115 million |publisher=Stereophile.com |date=August 16, 1998 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} [[File:Blockbenv.jpg|thumb|Blockbuster [[DVD-by-mail]] envelope]] In mid-2000, the company partnered with [[Enron]] in an attempt to create a video-on-demand service.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2000/07/20/mu4.html#49a68eba3541|title=Enron, Blockbuster Partner For Movie Mania|last=Schiffman|first=Betsy|date=July 20, 2000|work=Forbes.com|accessdate=March 28, 2018}} Initially, the partnership was supposed to last for 20 years, however, Enron chose to terminate the deal in March 2001 over fears that Blockbuster would not be able to provide sufficient films for the service.{{cite web|title=Blockbuster's Broadband-Video Deal Collapses|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/mar/11/news/mn-36306|website=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Bloomberg News|accessdate=27 October 2016}} Also in 2000 Blockbuster turned down a chance to purchase the still fledgling [[Netflix]] for $50 million.{{cite news| title= Your late fees are waived: Blockbuster closes | first=Todd | last= Leopold | publisher= CNN| date=November 6, 2013 | quote= Even Blockbuster's late fees came back to bite the chain in an unlikely way. In 1997, a man named [[Reed Hastings]] returned a late copy of ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]'' to his local Blockbuster. He was assessed a $40 fee. Two years later, he founded Netflix. Blockbuster was caught flat-footed by many of these changes. It could have purchased Netflix for $50 million in 2000, but passed. As Netflix rose, Blockbuster's attempts to compete on Netflix's terms—especially through the mail—foundered. It also tried to compete with [[Redbox]] using standalone [[kiosk]]s. That didn't work, either.}} In 2002, Blockbuster acquired Movie Trading Company, a Dallas chain that buys, sells, and trades movies and games, to study potential business models for DVD and game trading. Also that year, it acquired [[Gamestation]], a 64-store UK computer and console games retailer chain, and purchased DVD Rental Central for $1 million, an Arizona father-and-son online DVD-rental company with about ten thousand subscribers. DVD Rental Central would eventually turn into Blockbuster Online.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=sodDcL2yhsIC&pg=PT67&dq=Blockbuster+Online+DVD+Rental+central&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0t9CpxZDaAhVGjSwKHa1EDV8Q6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=Blockbuster+Online+DVD+Rental+central&f=false|title=Netflixed: The Epic Battle for America's Eyeballs|first=Gina|last=Keating|date=October 11, 2012|publisher=Penguin|accessdate=July 13, 2018|via=Google Books}} In October 2004, Blockbuster was officially spun-off from Viacom. Online DVD subscription was introduced on Blockbuster.com, also known as Blockbuster Online.{{cite press release |url=http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=563 |title=With Several Million U.S. Households as Potential Customers, Blockbuster Plans to Capture Substantial Share of Online Rentals |publisher=Blockbuster MediaRoom |date=December 31, 2003 |accessdate=January 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201174655/http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=563 |archivedate=December 1, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Blockbuster also rolled out its "Game Rush" store-in-store concept to approximately 450 domestic company-operated stores. Blockbuster began game and DVD trading in select U.S. stores.{{cite press release |url=http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=574 |title=Blockbuster Launches National DVD and Game Trading Program |publisher=Blockbuster MediaRoom |date=October 25, 2004 |accessdate=January 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201174710/http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=574 |archivedate=December 1, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} At its peak in 2004, Blockbuster had more than 9,000 stores in the U.S. In December 2004, Blockbuster announced its intention to pursue a hostile [[takeover]] of [[Hollywood Video]], its major U.S. competitor.{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/905895/000119312504220268/dex991.htm |title=Press Release |publisher=sec.gov |accessdate=May 28, 2015}} After some extensions of the tender offer, Blockbuster eventually gave up due primarily to resistance from the [[Federal Trade Commission|FTC]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/03/26/business/media/26movie.html |title=Blockbuster Ends Bid for Rival |publisher=nytimes.com |accessdate=May 28, 2015}} In response to the Blockbuster offer, Hollywood Video agreed to a buyout in January 2005 by a smaller competitor, the [[Dothan, Alabama]]-based [[Movie Gallery]]. Since then, Movie Gallery has filed for bankruptcy twice and its entire chain of stores has been liquidated. In May 2005, financier [[Carl Icahn]] waged a successful [[proxy fight]] to add himself and two other members to the board. Icahn accused Blockbuster of overpaying chairman and CEO John F. Antioco, who had served in that capacity since 1997, receiving $51.6 million in compensation for 2004. Icahn was also at odds with Antioco on how to revive profit at Blockbuster; Antioco scrapped late fees in January, started an internet service, and wanted to keep the company independent, while Icahn wanted to sell out to a [[private equity]] firm.{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/business/carl-icahn-wins-seat-on-blockbusters-board/13719/ |title=Carl Icahn Wins Seat on Blockbuster's Board – May 12, 2005 – The New York Sun |publisher=Nysun.com |date=May 12, 2005 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} Also in 2005 Blockbuster began running a campaign promoting a "No more late fees" policy.{{cite web|last1=Carr|first1=Austin|title=Blockbuster Bankruptcy: A Decade of Decline|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/1690654/blockbuster-bankruptcy-decade-decline|website=Fastcompany|accessdate=27 October 2016}} The campaign proved controversial with [[Associated Press]] reporting that the new policy actually charged users the full price of the movie or game after eight days which they could cancel by returning the product in question and paying a fee.{{cite web|title=Blockbuster Settles Over 'No Late Fees'|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1414947/blockbuster-settles-over-no-late-fees|website=Billboardbiz|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=27 October 2016}} More than 40 states filed suit against the company for false advertising. Blockbuster would later settle the suit agreeing to refund customers as well as promising to better explain the policy. In 2006, [[Vintage Stock (retailer)|Vintage Stock]] acquired the Movie Trading Company name from Blockbuster and continues to use the name for Dallas-area stores.{{cite web|url=http://www.vintagestock.com/about-vintage-stock|title=About Us - Vintage Stock / Movie Trading Co. - Music, Movies, Video Games and More!|publisher=|accessdate=December 17, 2016}} A billion-dollar campaign called Total Access was introduced in 2007 as a strategy against Netflix. Through Blockbuster Online customers could rent a DVD online and receive a new movie for free when they returned it to a Blockbuster store. While it was a major success every free movie cost the company two dollars, but the hope was that it would attract enough new subscribers to cover the loss. Netflix felt threatened, and Hastings approached Antioco with a suggestion to buy Blockbuster's online business. In return, a new system would be introduced where customers could return their movies to a Blockbuster store. Before the deal could be realized, investor Carl Icahn interfered. Icahn refused to let the company lose more money through Total Access. Antioco was pushed out and replaced with James Keyes, who rejected Hasting's proposal, raised the price on online DVD rentals and put an end to the free movie deal. As a consequence, Blockbuster Online's previously massive growth quickly stopped.{{cite web|url=https://www.fool.com/investing/general/2013/11/14/how-blockbuster-almost-beat-netfilx.aspx|title=How Blockbuster Almost Beat Netfilx|first=Aaron|last=Sankin|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In July Antioco left the company, reportedly due to continued controversy over his compensation. He left with a $24.7 million severance package.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2034688520070320 | agency=Reuters | title=UPDATE 5-Blockbuster CEO to leave with lower pay package | date=March 20, 2007 | first=Gina | last=Keating}} On June 19, 2007, after a pilot program launched in late 2006, Blockbuster announced that it had chosen [[Blu-ray]] over [[HD DVD]] rental format to rent in a majority of its stores. In the pilot program, Blockbuster offered selected titles for rental and sale in 250 stores. Blockbuster stocked Blu-ray titles in almost 5,000 stores across the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, Mexico, and Australia.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvpredictions.com/blockbusterblu041008.htm |title=Blockbuster: Blu-ray In Almost 5,000 Stores |publisher=TVpredictions.com |date=April 10, 2008 |accessdate=June 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720172603/http://www.tvpredictions.com/blockbusterblu041008.htm |archivedate=July 20, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ===2007–2011: James Keyes era=== On July 2, 2007, the company named [[James W. Keyes]], former president and CEO of [[7-Eleven]], as the new chairman and CEO. He introduced a new business strategy that included enhancements to existing stores along with a shift to streaming video with the acquisition of MovieLink in September 2008. Part of the plan was to de-emphasize the unprofitable Total Access (DVD-by-mail) service, in favor of online streaming. In December 2008, he still ignored both Netflix and Redbox, focusing on Apple and Walmart instead; "Neither RedBox nor Netflix are even on the radar screen in terms of competition. It's more Walmart and Apple."{{cite web|url=https://www.fool.com/investing/general/2008/12/10/blockbuster-ceo-has-answers.aspx|title=Blockbuster CEO Has Answers|first=Rick|last=Munarriz|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} On September 14, 2007, Blockbuster GB Ltd bought a number of retail stores from ChoicesUK plc. ChoicesUK is an AIM-listed multi-channel distributor and retailer of DVDs, computer games, and CDs. The sale secured employment for approximately 450 employees across 59 stores in the UK. As part of the transaction, Blockbuster GB rebranded the stores as Blockbuster.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} On February 17, 2008, Blockbuster proposed a buyout of struggling [[Circuit City Stores|Circuit City]]. However, after a [[due diligence]] review of Circuit City's financial books, Blockbuster withdrew its offer in July 2008. Analysts were not favorable to the proposed deal, viewing it as a desperate effort to save two struggling retailers rather than a bold turnaround initiative.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1436008820080414 | agency=Reuters | title=Blockbuster-Circuit City deal gets thumbs down | date=April 14, 2008}} Subsequently, Circuit City filed for bankruptcy on November 10, 2008 and, after liquidating all of its stores, ceased operations on March 8, 2009.{{cite web|last=Musil |first=Steven |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-10784_3-9982618-7.html |title= Blockbuster abandons Circuit City bid | News Blog – CNET News |publisher=cnet.com |date=July 1, 2008 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} At the beginning of 2010, Blockbuster had over 6,500 stores, of which 4,000 were in the U.S.,{{cite web |url = http://www.blockbuster.com/corporate/internationalOperations |title = retrieved 2009-10-04 |publisher = Blockbuster.com |accessdate = June 16, 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110720065329/http://www.blockbuster.com/corporate/internationalOperations |archivedate = July 20, 2011 |df = mdy-all }} a number that had been reduced to 3,425 in late October the same year.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-10-20/entertainment/ct-live-1020-video-stores-borrelli-20101020_1_video-stores-movie-gallery-specialty-video|title=The decline of video stores: What we'll miss the most|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In the United States, it planned to close between 810 and 960 retail stores and instead launch as many as 10,000 "Blockbuster Express" video rental kiosks by the middle of 2010.Talley, Karen (October 1, 2009). [http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091001-714416.html "Blockbuster Plans Expansion To Counter Raft Of Competition".] The Wall Street Journal. It has been claimed that more than 43 million U.S. households had Blockbuster memberships.{{cite press release |url=http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=616 |title=Blockbuster Reports Fourth quarter And Full Year Results Revenues Top $6.1 Billion |publisher=Blockbuster MediaRoom |accessdate=January 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201174856/http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=616 |archivedate=December 1, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} [[File:Blockbuster, Moor Allerton District Centre.jpg|thumb|right|A Blockbuster store in [[Moor Allerton]], [[Leeds]]]] On February 10, 2010, Blockbuster announced that it would cease all its operations in Portugal, closing down 17 outlets and leaving over 100 workers unemployed. Blockbuster representatives in Portugal blamed [[internet piracy]] and the lack of government response to it as the key factors to the company's failure in the country.{{cite press release|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/02/10/blockbuster-files-for-bankruptcy-in-portugal-blames-internet-pi/ |title=Blockbuster files for bankruptcy in Portugal, and blames internet piracy. |publisher=Engadget |date=February 10, 2010 |accessdate=February 16, 2010}} In March 2010, Blockbuster began "Additional Daily Rates", or "ADRs", for rentals not returned by their due date in the United States, having already used this procedure in other countries such as the UK for many years. An ADR was charged for each day a member kept the rental beyond the rental terms. On March 12, 2010, [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]], Blockbuster's independent registered public accounting firm, issued its audit opinion disclosing substantial doubt about Blockbuster's ability to continue as a [[going concern]]. This report was included in Blockbusters's 10-K SEC filing. On March 17, 2010, Blockbuster issued a bankruptcy warning after continued drops in revenue threatened its ability to service its nearly $1 billion debt load. By April 1, 2010, Carl Icahn had resigned from Blockbuster's board of directors and sold nearly all his remaining Blockbuster stock.{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/globe-investor-blog/carl-icahn-unwinding-blockbuster-stake/article1521533/|location=Canada|work=The Globe and Mail|first=Jonathan|last=Stempel|title=Carl Icahn unwinding Blockbuster stake|date=April 2, 2010}} Blockbuster paired up with [[Time Warner]] to have [[Warner Bros.]] movies made available in Blockbuster stores on the DVD release date and not be subject to a four-week delay.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} Similar agreements were also made with [[Universal Studios|Universal]] and [[20th Century Fox]]. In May 2010, the liquidation of [[Movie Gallery]] began, eliminating Blockbuster's primary competitor. During the same month, a dissident shareholder, Gregory S. Meyer, in an effort to be elected to Blockbuster's board of directors, engaged in a [[proxy battle]] with Blockbuster's board, alleging that the board had been responsible for significant destruction of value to shareholders. Meyer was elected to the board at Blockbuster's shareholder meeting in Dallas on June 24, 2010. On July 1, 2010, the company was delisted from the [[New York Stock Exchange]] after its shareholders failed to pass a [[reverse stock split]] plan aimed at heading off involuntary delisting because of the stock's trading at well below $1 per share.{{cite news|last=Dobuzinskis|first=Alex|title=Blockbuster says to delist from NYSE|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/32156/20100702/blockbuster-says-to-delist-from-nyse.htm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120708072947/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/32156/20100702/blockbuster-says-to-delist-from-nyse.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 8, 2012|accessdate=September 26, 2010|work=Thomson Reuters|publisher=International Business Times|date=July 2, 2010}} The stock was then traded on the [[OTC Bulletin Board|OTCBB]] (over-the-counter bulletin board). Blockbuster was unable to make a $42.4 million interest payment to bondholders and was given until August 13, 2010 to pay off the debt. The company hired Jeff Stegenga to be its chief restructuring officer (CRO) in an effort to satisfy bondholder demands and recapitalize the company. After failing to pay on August 13, bondholders gave Blockbuster until September 30, 2010. On August 26, 2010, news media reported that Blockbuster was planning to file a pre-packaged Chapter 11 bankruptcy in mid-September. In light of this news, the company's chief financial officer (CFO), Tom Casey, resigned on September 11. He was replaced by Dennis McGill, formerly CFO of Safety-Kleen Systems, Inc. On September 23, 2010, Blockbuster filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection]] due to challenging losses, $900 million in debt, and strong competition from [[Netflix]], [[Redbox]], and video on-demand services.James Surowiecki, The Next Level, The New Yorker, October 18, 2010.{{cite web|title=Blockbuster Chapter 11 Petition|url=http://www.pacermonitor.com/view/PXDYCPY/Blockbuster_Inc.__nysbke-10-14997__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|publisher=PacerMonitor|accessdate=2 May 2016}} [[Movie Gallery|Movie Gallery/Hollywood Video]] had filed for [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7 bankruptcy liquidation]] earlier in 2010 for similar reasons.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/09/23/blockbuster-files-for-chapter-11/|title=Blockbuster files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy|first=Thomas|last=Ricker|date=September 23, 2010|publisher=[[Engadget]]|format=blog|accessdate=February 19, 2011}} At the time of its Chapter 11 filing, Blockbuster said it would keep its 3,300 stores open; In December 2010, Blockbuster announced it would close an additional 182 stores by the end of April 2011 in attempts to emerge from bankruptcy.{{cite news|title=Blockbuster plans to close 182 stores by April|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40753485/ns/business-retail/|agency=Reuters|date=December 20, 2010|accessdate=December 29, 2010}} It was reported in February 2011 that Blockbuster and its creditors had not come up with a Chapter 11 exit plan and that the company would be sold for $300 million or more, along with taking over debts and leases.{{cite news|url=http://www.citizen-times.com/article/20110211/BUSINESS/110211010/1003/business/Report-Blockbuster-plans-put-itself-up-sale|title=Report: Blockbuster plans to put itself up for sale|work=[[USA Today]] |date=February 11, 2011|accessdate=February 11, 2011}} Blockbuster has admitted that it may not be able to meet financial obligations required under its Chapter 11 filing, a circumstance which could mandate conversion of the bankruptcy filing to Chapter 7 (liquidation).{{Citation|last=Ruth|first=Eric|date=February 18, 2011|title=Blockbuster to close most Delaware locations: Liquidations to begin this month|periodical=[[DelawareOnline]]|publisher=[[Gannett]]|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20110219/BUSINESS/102190324/-1/NLETTER01/Blockbuster-to-close-most-Del.-locations|oclc=38962480|accessdate=February 19, 2011}} On March 1, 2011, the [[U.S. Department of Justice]] filed a claim disclosing that Blockbuster did not have the funds to continue reorganizing and should liquidate. On March 28, 2011, South Korean telecommunications company [[SK Telecom]] made a surprise bid to buy Blockbuster.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestreet.com/story/11061428/1/blockbuster-receives-surprise-bid-from-korea-report.html?cm_ven=RSSFeed|title=Blockbuster Receives Surprise Bid From Korea: Report|author=Jeanine Poggi|publisher=TheStreet}} [[Dish Network]] had also expressed interest in bidding, as did [[Carl Icahn]], despite calling Blockbuster "the worst investment I ever made".{{cite news|last=Spector |first=Mike |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703806304576244722306644968 |title=Blockbuster Auction Gets Under Way With Dish Bid |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=April 6, 2011 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} Dish eventually won the auction on April 6, 2011, agreeing to buy Blockbuster for $320 million and the assumption of $87 million in liabilities and other obligations. On April 19, 2011, it was announced that Dish would keep only 500 Blockbuster stores open. The acquisition was completed on April 26, 2011.{{cite web |url=http://dishnetwork.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=8778&item=31591 |title=Dish Network agrees to acquire blockbuster assets |publisher=Dishnetwork.mediaroom.com |accessdate=June 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721175542/http://dishnetwork.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=8778&item=31591 |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} In April 2011, Dish Network told the U.S. Bankruptcy Court that it needed more time to negotiate with landlords in an effort to keep more than 600 Blockbuster stores open.Maria Halkias, ''Dallas News''. "[http://www.dallasnews.com/business/retail/20110421-dish-network-is-trying-to-keep-more-than-600-blockbuster-stores-open.ece Dish Network is trying to keep more than 600 Blockbuster stores open]". April 21, 2011. Retrieved April 22, 2011. In April 2011, Blockbuster's landlords objected to its assumption of leases that it sought to assign to soon-to-be-owner [[Dish Network]] Corp., claiming that they did not have adequate assurance that the new owner would honor those leases. Blockbuster signed a deal with [[ITV Studios|ITV Studios Global Entertainment]] to launch ITV Programmes released on DVDs, Blu-rays, etc.Joseph Checkler, NASDAQ. "[http://www.nasdaq.com/aspx/stock-market-news-story.aspx?storyid=201104201431dowjonesdjonline000558&title=blockbuster-landlords-want-more-assurancemoney-for-leases Blockbuster Landlords Want More Assurance, Money For Leases]". April 21, 2011. Retrieved April 22, 2011. ===2011–2015: Michael Kelly era=== On May 6, 2011, Keyes resigned as Blockbuster's CEO, being replaced by Michael Kelly under the new title of president. On August 31, 2011, the liquidators announced the closure of the remaining 253 Canadian stores and shutting of the entire Canadian unit.{{Citation|title=Blockbuster Canada closing its doors|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/story/2011/08/31/blockbuster-canada-close.html|periodical=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]|oclc=|accessdate=August 31, 2011|date=August 31, 2011}} [[File:BlockBuster-Video-Store-Closed.jpg|thumb|right|Former Blockbuster store in [[the Midwest]].]] On September 2011 it was announced that Blockbuster and Dish Network would launch a new service called Blockbuster Movie Pass that would compete with Netflix. For US$10 per month the members would have access to both a streaming service and movies and games-by-mail. But the package was only available for subscribers of Dish Network's pay-TV service, and it eventually folded.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/09/23/blockbuster-movie-pass-dish-networks-answer-to-netflix-and-qwikster/|title=Blockbuster Movie Pass: Dish Network's $10/Month Answer To Netflix|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/blockbuster-movie-pass-no-netflix-killer/|title=Blockbuster Movie Pass no Netflix killer|date=September 23, 2011|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} On January 13, 2012, Dish CEO Aaron Kask announced that while Dish had planned to keep 90% of the stores in operation, meaning around 15,000 employees would remain employed, because of market factors "there are ones that aren't going to make it. We will close unprofitable stores. We will close additional stores." Kask did not say when these additional closings would happen and only remarked that some stores were unprofitable.
