{{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=July 12, 2018 |title=Blockbuster in Bend, Oregon, the last in the nation |url=http://kpic.com/news/offbeat/blockbuster-in-bend-last-in-the-nation |publisher=[[KPIC]] |location=[[Roseburg, Oregon]] |access-date=August 29, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/07/12/theres-1-blockbuster-left-in-the-us-and-its-owner-refuses-to-close|title=There's 1 Blockbuster left in the US and it refuses to close|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[New York Post]]|date=July 12, 2018|accessdate=August 29, 2018}} ==Business model== {{Refimprove section|date=December 2009}} The standard business model for video rental stores had traditionally been to pay a large flat fee per video, approximately $65, and offer unlimited rentals for the lifetime of the medium itself. [[Sumner Redstone]], whose Viacom conglomerate then owned Blockbuster, personally pioneered a new revenue-sharing arrangement for video in the mid-1980s. Blockbuster obtained videos for little cost and kept a 60% of the rental fee, paying the other 40% to the studio, and reporting rental information through [[Rentrak]]. In addition to benefiting from a lower initial price, Blockbuster also capitalized on the fact that movies were generally not available for purchase at affordable price points during initial release periods. Thus customers had a choice to rent, wait, or buy the film on tape at the much higher [[Manufacturer's Suggested Retail Price|manufacturer's suggested retail price]] targeted at other rental chains and film enthusiasts, which at that time ranged between $70–$100 per title.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} ===Quantity and selection of titles=== Blockbuster stores followed a strategy of emphasizing access to the most popular new releases, obtaining early access and stocking many copies of the new-release titles, with a relatively smaller depth of selection than traditional independent video stores.{{cite web |last=Adams |first=Nathan |date=February 22, 2011 |url=https://filmschoolrejects.com/anyone-want-to-buy-blockbuster-d8b5d4d0e8b7/ |title=Anyone Want to Buy Blockbuster? |access-date=April 1, 2018}} Much of the shelf space in the stores was devoted to popular titles that were placed relatively sparsely on the shelves with the entire front cover visible, so customers could browse casually and quickly, rather than having a more diverse selection with fewer copies of each title. In contrast, independent video rental shops typically tended to stock a broad selection of older titles that were placed densely on shelves with only the spines visible as in a traditional book library. Blockbuster sometimes contracted with studios to obtain earlier access to new titles than other companies could achieve. Examples of such contracts were those in which Blockbuster became the exclusive rental chain for new releases from the [[WWE]], [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]], [[DreamWorks]], [[Universal Studios]], [[The Weinstein Company]], [[Miramax]], [[Lionsgate]], [[Disney]], [[20th Century Fox]], [[MGM]], [[Sony]], [[Image Entertainment]], [[Warner Bros.]], [[New Line Cinema]] and Allumination FilmWorks.{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/media/2006-11-15-blockbuster-weinsteins_x.htm | work=[[USA Today]] |agency=[[Reuters]] | title=Blockbuster signs deal to be exclusive renter for Weinsteins | date=November 15, 2006 | accessdate=April 26, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.times-news.com/news/local_news/agreement-gives-blockbuster-exclusive-access-to-new-release-warner-bros/article_b70de4b8-a4c7-5355-93be-e6c4ee46b57e.html|title=Agreement gives Blockbuster exclusive access to new release Warner Bros. films|first=Cory GalliherCumberland|last=Times-News|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} As one commentator complained, "Blockbuster was once an unstoppable giant whose franchises swept across the country putting mom and pop video stores out of business left and right by offering a larger selection of new releases, pricing them at a lower point due to the volume they worked in... Gone were the fragmented, independently owned shops that were often unorganized treasure troves of VHS discoveries. In their place were walls of new releases: hundreds of copies of a small handful of films. Everyone watching the same thing, everyone developing the same limited set of expectations... They put focus entirely on what was new rather than on discovering film history ..." When a title was no longer a new release, each store would retain a few copies of it and typically sell off the rest as "previously viewed" for discounted prices.{{cite web|url=http://www.fthismovie.net/2017/09/riske-business-do-you-dig-on.html|title=Riske Business: Do You Dig on Busterverses?|last=Riske|first=Adam|date=September 12, 2017|publisher=fthismovie.net|accessdate=January 7, 2018}} Older movies would be re-categorized as "Blockbuster Favorite" titles and placed in a different area of the store.{{cite news|title=We Promise You Will Go Home Happy|date=November 6, 1997|work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|page=75}} Most Blockbuster locations also accepted trade-ins of used movies, TV shows, and games.{{cite news|url=http://www.myce.com/news/Blockbuster-nationwide-DVD-and-game-trading-program-9332/|title=Blockbuster nationwide DVD and game trading program|date=October 28, 2004|accessdate=April 26, 2010}} Since Blockbuster's founding in 1985, the chain refused to stock [[Pornographic film|adult films]] in order to portray the brand as family-friendly.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestreet.com/story/10867574/1/the-rise-and-fall-of-blockbuster-the-long-rewinding-road.html|title=Blockbuster's Rise and Fall: The Long, Rewinding Road|last=Poggi|first=Jeanine|date=September 23, 2010|publisher=TheStreet, Inc.|accessdate=January 7, 2018}} However, the company did carry [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|R-rated]] and unrated films. ==Other ventures== ===Blockbuster Entertainment Awards=== {{Main|Blockbuster Entertainment Awards}} Blockbuster Entertainment Inc. ran an awards show annually from 1995 to 2001 called the ''Blockbuster Entertainment Awards''. In November 2001, Blockbuster announced that it would cancel the 2002 award show following concerns about viewership and celebrity attendance after the [[September 11 attacks]].{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20396305_185459,00.html |title=Trophy Case |last1=Susman |first1=Gary |date=November 22, 2001 |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher= |accessdate=May 15, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.berkeleydailyplanet.com/issue/2001-11-24/article/8505?headline=Viewership-uncertainty-causes-Blockbuster-to-cancel-awards--The-Associated-Press |title=Viewership uncertainty causes Blockbuster to cancel awards |date=November 24, 2001 |website=[[Berkeley Daily Planet]] |publisher= |accessdate=May 15, 2013}} ===Blockbuster Express=== Blockbuster Express was a movie-rental kiosk brand sublicensed for use by [[licensee]] [[NCR Corporation]]. In 2011, nearly 10,000 Blockbuster Express kiosks were in operation.{{cite web|title=NCR Exploring 'Options' for Blockbuster Express Including Sale|url=http://www.homemediamagazine.com/blockbuster-express/ncr-exploring-options-blockbuster-express-including-sale-25493|publisher=Home Media Magazine|accessdate=October 28, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030162141/http://www.homemediamagazine.com/blockbuster-express/ncr-exploring-options-blockbuster-express-including-sale-25493|archivedate=October 30, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blockbusterexpress.com/ |publisher=Internet Archive |title=Wayback Machine: blockbusterexpress.com |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914072629/http://www.blockbusterexpress.com/ |archivedate=September 14, 2010 |df=mdy }} Apart from the license to use the Blockbuster brand name, Blockbuster Express kiosks are unrelated to Blockbuster LLC, its stores, its DVD-by-mail service, or its online streaming service. The names ''Blockbuster Express''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1608945|title=Blockbuster Express - Cold Bath Road|accessdate=November 4, 2014|date=December 5, 2009}} and ''Blockbuster Video Express''{{cite web|url=http://www.burytimes.co.uk/news/10165554.display/|title=Blockbuster goes into administration|accessdate=November 4, 2014|date=January 16, 2013}} had also been used for certain Blockbuster retail stores in the United Kingdom. ===GameRush=== [[File:Blockbuster Blue Ash OH USA.JPG|thumb|GameRush store at a Blockbuster in [[Blue Ash, Ohio]]]] In the summer of 2003, Blockbuster started converting some stores to GameRush stores. These stores sold and bought DVDs, games, game consoles, and accessories. GameRush was positioned as a direct competitor to stores such as [[GameStop]] and [[Game Crazy]]. Blockbuster used its location status to get instant coverage; it also promoted these stores by hosting video-game tournaments, special trade-in offers, and a more "hip" look to the selection and staff. However, when Blockbuster introduced the discontinuation of late fees, GameRush was put on the chopping block. In April 2007, GameRush stores were reduced back to just a games section. ===Discovery Zone=== Blockbuster invested in the indoor kids play restaurant [[Discovery Zone]]. In 1995, Blockbuster bought more stock to take control of the company. The Discovery Zone chain closed in 1999. ==International operations== ===Australia and New Zealand=== {{Expand section|date=August 2018}} [[File:Blockbuster Video Wagga Wagga.jpg|thumb|right|A Blockbuster Video store in [[Wagga Wagga Marketplace]], [[New South Wales]]]] [[File:Blockbuster Hobart Australia.jpg|thumb|right|A Blockbuster store in [[Sandy Bay, Tasmania|Sandy Bay]], an inner-suburb of [[Hobart]], [[Tasmania]]]] In Australia, the first Blockbuster store was opened in 1991 in [[Melbourne]]. In 1992, the [[Virgin Group]] and Blockbuster Inc entered into a joint venture to set up Australia's first [[Virgin Megastores]] in [[Sydney]], Melbourne, and [[Adelaide]]. This lasted until Virgin sold its interest in the six stores to Blockbuster, which promptly rebranded them in 1993 as Blockbuster Music. In 1994 Australian store numbers rose to 54 with the acquisition of Major Video and Focus chains in both [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[South Australia]]. In 1995, the growth continued with the opening of the 100th video store in the country. By the end of 1998, Blockbuster Australia opened over 125 stores. In July 1998, Blockbuster Australia launched into [[franchising]] with the conversion of the former Video Flicks franchise group in [[Queensland]], and the former Movieland group in [[Western Australia]] six months later. Also in 1998, the company sold its last two Australian Blockbuster Music stores in [[Pitt Street]], [[Sydney]], and [[Chapel Street, Melbourne]] to Brazin Limited, which incorporated them under its [[Sanity Entertainment]] brand. Throughout 1999 and 2000, Blockbuster Australia quickly expanded its franchise store network through the conversion of smaller groups and the granting of individual franchises. Before 2005, this was done through the acquisition of the Movies Plus Group and the conversion of some individual Movies 4U and Movieland outlets.{{cite web | url=http://www.onlysydney.com.au/shopping-services/music-video-dvd/rental-outlets/blockbuster | title=Blockbuster Australia: New South Wales stores | publisher=Only Sydney | accessdate=March 26, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327131536/http://www.onlysydney.com.au/shopping-services/music-video-dvd/rental-outlets/blockbuster | archivedate=March 27, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.arnnet.com.au/article/116624/brazin_acquires_brashs/|title=Brazin acquires Brashs|first=Ellen|last=Cresswell|work=[[International Data Group|ARN]]|date=April 22, 1998|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/blockbuster-inc-history/ | title=Blockbuster Inc. History | publisher=Funding Universe | accessdate=March 29, 2013 }} In February 2007, Blockbuster sold its entire Australian store network to Video Ezy Australasia Pty Ltd. The store layout was similar to a regular American store with a Game Rush, but instead of games it offers electronics goods like computers and DVD players, groceries like candies and microwave popcorn, and even toys from [[Mattel]] and [[Hasbro]]'s board games. In January 2007, when Blockbuster had 127 stores across Brazil, it sold its Brazilian stake for $87.4 million and gave Lojas Americanas exclusive rights to the Blockbuster brand in the country for 20 years. The average store has an interior on about 400 m2, where 80-100 m2 is dedicated to movies.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-americanas-acquisition/retailer-americanas-buys-brazil-blockbuster-stores-idUSN2435322120070124|title=Retailer Americanas buys Brazil Blockbuster stores|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.varejista.com.br/cases/5676/lojas-americanas|title=Lojas Americanas|date=February 19, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} ===Canada=== [[File:BlockbusterMoncton.JPG|thumb|right|A Blockbuster store in [[Moncton]], New Brunswick, Canada, which featured the 1985–1997 logo]] In Canada, Blockbuster Canada (established in 1990) had operated independently, and it initially remained financially stable.{{cite news|last=Shaw|first=Hollie|title=Business as usual for Blockbuster Canada|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/business/fp/Business+usual+Blockbuster+Canada/3568643/story.html|accessdate=September 26, 2010|work=Vancouver Sun|date=September 23, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926120746/http://www.vancouversun.com/business/fp/Business+usual+Blockbuster+Canada/3568643/story.html|archive-date=September 26, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} It began a partnership with [[Wind Mobile]] in December 2009, selling mobile phones at all stores in cities where Wind's service was available. Phone sales began in [[Toronto]] and [[Calgary]], later expanding to other cities with Wind coverage. Some stores even featured a full Wind "store-in-a-store" for postpaid activations and a larger selection of devices.{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/wind-mobile-to-partner-with-blockbuster/article1399427/ | location=Canada |work=The Globe and Mail | title=Wind Mobile to partner with Blockbuster | date=December 14, 2009}} However, on May 3, 2011, it was announced that the company had gone into receivership.{{cite news|last=Berkow|first=Jomeson|title=Blockbuster Canada goes bust|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/business/Blockbuster+Canada+goes+bust/4737781/story.html|accessdate=May 9, 2011|work=Financial Post|date=May 6, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509063838/http://www.vancouversun.com/business/Blockbuster+Canada+goes+bust/4737781/story.html|archive-date=May 9, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} On May 25, 2011, it was announced that 146 stores, accounting for approximately 35% of the company's stores in Canada, would be shut down effective June 18, 2011. On August 31, 2011, Blockbuster Canada announced that no buyer could be found for its remaining stores that were acceptable to the court-appointed bankruptcy receiver, and that it would wind down operations and close all stores by December 31, 2011. The company had acted as a guarantor towards Blockbuster's remaining debt.{{cite news |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/blockbuster-to-pull-plug-in-canada/article2149222/ |title=Blockbuster to pull plug in Canada |first1=Marina |last1=Strauss |first2=Iain |last2=Marlow |date=August 31, 2011}} ===Denmark=== Blockbuster came to Denmark in 1996 with the acquisition of the 29 [[Christianshavn]] video stores.{{cite web|url=https://politiken.dk/kultur/filmogtv/art5487402/Milliardg%C3%A6ld-truer-verdens-st%C3%B8rste-filmudlejningsk%C3%A6de|title=Milliardgæld truer verdens største filmudlejningskæde|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In 2009 they were on its peak with 72 stores across the country.{{cite web|url=https://www.business.dk/detailhandel/nu-lukker-blockbuster-butikker|title=Nu lukker Blockbuster butikker|date=July 17, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} Blockbuster Video Denmark sold the rights for the Blockbuster brand to the Danish telecommunications corporation TDC in 2013, excluding the 46 remaining brick and mortar stores which continued as RecycleIT A/S, diversifying in refurbishing and reselling consumer electronics in addition sale and rental of games and movies.{{cite web|url=http://detailfolk.dk/detailnyheder/tdc_koeber_danske_blockbuster.html?prsrc=3|title=TDC køber danske Blockbuster|website=detailfolk.dk|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} The original goal was to rename all the stores before 1 July 2014, when TDC would get the exclusive rights to the brand name in Denmark, but only 12 of them had been renamed at the end of June and RecycleIT A/S filed for bankruptcy the same year.{{cite web|url=http://flatpanels.dk/test.php?subaction=showfull&id=1404203885|title=TDC: iTunes bliver største konkurrent til Blockbuster test - FlatpanelsDK|website=flatpanels.dk|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.flatpanels.dk/nyhed.php?subaction=showfull&id=1406269924|title=Fra Blockbuster til RecycleIT til Bluecity - FlatpanelsDK|website=www.flatpanels.dk|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} The 12 RecycleIT stores were bought by the company Blue City.{{cite web|url=http://www.recordere.dk/2014/08/blue-city-viderefoerer-blockbuster-koncept/|title=Blue City viderefører Blockbuster-koncept - recordere.dk|date=August 2, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} The new owners planned to gradually phase out game and movie sales and rental within 2016, but due to the fast changes in the market it happened almost immediately after the takeover, and seven of the stores, therefore, closed in 2015. As of 2017, the five remaining ones had started to make some profit, and focus exclusively on second-hand consumer electronics{{cite web|url=https://www.retailnews.dk/article/view/468696/blue_city_er_tradt_ud_af_blockbusters_skygge|title=Blue City er trådt ud af Blockbusters skygge|website=RetailNews|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} However, the Blockbuster On Demand service is still active in Nordic Countries, offering both unlimited streaming and 48-hour rental of films online. Several [[Smart TV]]s have the Blockbuster app pre-installed out-of-the-box, and it is available on a variety of streaming devices such as Google's Chromecast.{{cite web |title=About Blockbuster (Denmark) |url=http://blockbuster.dk/om/}} ===Germany=== Blockbuster opened 20 stores in Berlin and Munich and announced plans to open 250 more.{{When|date=July 2018}} The chain presented itself as family friendly by not renting pornographic films. However, that decision left a gap in the profitability of the stores. Blockbuster left the German market in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.wiwo.de/unternehmen/videotheken-blockbuster-ist-pleite/5682592.html |title=Blockbuster ist pleite |publisher=[[WirtschaftsWoche]] | date = September 23, 2010 |accessdate=April 28, 2017}} ===Ireland=== In March 2010, Blockbuster announced that it intended to sell all operations in Europe. The company once had an Irish subsidiary, [[Xtravision]], which did not operate under the Blockbuster [[brand name]]. Blockbuster sold Xtravision at a loss in August 2009 to Birchhall Investments Limited. In early 2016 it was decided to close all of its 83 stores except for its online business and vending machines.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/xtra-vision-killed-by-christmas-sales-collapse-court-told-1.2512923|title=Xtra-vision killed by Christmas sales collapse, court told|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/no-sequel-as-final-credits-roll-for-xtra-vision-1.2515757|title=No sequel as final credits roll for Xtra-vision|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} ===Israel=== In the late 2000s at its peak, Blockbuster Israel had 40 branches and more than 260 automated video rentals.{{cite web|url=https://www.ima.org.il/yahadclub|title=מועדון יחד - מועדון צרכנות לרופאים -|first=|last=SLATECH|website=מועדון יחד - מועדון צרכנות לרופאים - ההסתדרות הרפואית בישראל|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000730869#utm_source=social&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=facebook|title=14 סניפי טאוור רקורדס נסגרו; בלוקבסטר הפסיקה לפעול|first=אילנית|last=חיות|website=Globes|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In December 2011, Blockbuster closed off its last branch store, and had only 80 automated video rentals left. ===Japan=== In March 1991, [[Den Fujita|Fujita Den Trading]] (which was the [[master franchise]] owner of [[McDonald's]] in Japan) and Blockbuster Inc entered into a joint venture to established Japan's first Blockbuster Video stores. By October 1992, Fujita and Blockbuster opened 15 stores in the country – four of them next to McDonald's outlets and most being located in the [[Greater Tokyo Area|greater Tokyo area]]. Unlike Blockbuster's U.S. stores, each Japanese outlet only occupied about half the floor space at 5,000 square feet due to the country's more limited available real estate.{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1990-10-05/business/9002170929_1_blockbuster-wally-knief-den-fujita|title=Blockbuster Plans A Move Into Japan|first=Lane|last=Kelley|work=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=October 5, 1990|accessdate=April 7, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/1992-10-18/they-dont-call-it-blockbuster-for-nothing|title=They Don't Call It Blockbuster For Nothing|date=October 18, 1992|work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|accessdate=April 5, 2013}} By June 1996, 32 stores were in operation with a public aim for 150 by 1998. Blockbuster Japan faced heavy competition from [[Osaka]]-based video rental chain, [[Tsutaya (video store)|Tsutaya]], with its 817 outlets, but the company saw opportunity in the population having high [[VCR]] ownership levels (at around 75%), low satellite TV penetration (at around 27%), and well-ordered store layouts (unique for most local video stores).{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-06-18/business/fi-16261_1_blockbuster-video|title=Blockbuster Moving In on Japan's Video Market|first=Yuri|last=Kageyama|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 18, 1996|accessdate=April 7, 2013}} However, Blockbuster's business strategy of "wholesome home entertainment" saw it not stock [[adult entertainment]] or extreme [[horror films]] where they account for 35% of the Japanese video market. That meant Blockbuster was unable to fit into the Japanese market adequately and was put at a disadvantage to other businesses selling and renting these movies. In 1999, Blockbuster handed its remaining shares over to Fujita Den Trading and exited the Japanese market.{{cite web | url=http://www.gcrossinc.com/en/info_exampleFailure.htm | title=Examples of Failure for Market Entry into Japan | publisher=G-Cross Inc. | accessdate=April 5, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104003641/http://www.gcrossinc.com/en/info_exampleFailure.htm | archivedate=November 4, 2012 | df=mdy-all }} ===Mexico=== In September 2015, all remaining Blockbuster retail stores (263 in total) in Mexico had been converted to "The B Store", and the floor space dedicated to video rentals reduced from 70% to 20%, the remaining space being used for general technology and electronics sales. The re-branding occurred with the owners not renewing their license with Blockbuster and the imminent expiry of the existing license.{{cite web |url=http://expansion.mx/negocios/2015/09/18/blockbuster-desaparece-en-mexico-conoce-su-nueva-imagen |title=Blockbuster desaparece en México, lo sustituye The B-Store |website=[[Expansión (Mexico)|Expansión]] |date=September 21, 2015 |accessdate=August 26, 2016}} (in Spanish){{cite web|url=https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/farewell-blockbuster-here-comes-b-store/|title=Farewell Blockbuster, here comes The B-Store|date=September 21, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} In 2016, it was reported that all the remaining B-stores were closed.{{cite web|url=https://expansion.mx/empresas/2016/10/28/grupo-salinas-cierra-su-tienda-de-peliculas-the-b-store|title=Grupo Salinas pone fin a su tienda de películas The B Store|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} ===Norway=== In December 2002 the first Blockbuster store opened in Norway, and was followed by another store some months later in 2003, both located in Oslo. The hope was to acquire an already existing video chain. When that failed, it was made an attempt to build a Norwegian blockbuster chain from scratch. But both stores closed in the spring of 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.videomagasinet.no/artikkel/blockbuster-stenger-129-butikker/|title=Blockbuster stenger 129 butikker|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} ===Peru=== In 2007, Blockbuster announced that it plans to shut down its stores in Peru due to poor revenues, which it blamed on the effect of movie [[copyright infringement|piracy]].{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/industryNews/idUSN0341210720070105 | title=Blockbuster shuts down in Peru, piracy blamed | date=January 3, 2007 | agency=Reuters}} The company had already closed down its stores in Ecuador, Portugal and Costa Rica. El Salvador followed in 2010, and Argentina in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.latintimes.com/blockbuster-closing-all-its-stores-us-what-will-happen-few-stores-left-latin-america-132656|title=Blockbuster Closing All Its Stores In US; What Will Happen To The Few Stores Left in Latin America?|date=November 6, 2013|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} ===United Kingdom=== [[File:Blockbuster Express - Cold Bath Road - geograph.org.uk - 1608945 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|A "Blockbuster Express" shop in Harrogate, Yorkshire, typical of the smaller UK stores often located in established urban and suburban areas]] In 1989, the company entered the United Kingdom via its purchase of the 875-store Ritz Video chain for $135 million, from parent company Citivision. Ritz Video was Europe's largest rental chain, with a 20% share of the United Kingdom video market, and annual sales of about $150 million. The first re-branded Blockbuster outlet opened on [[Walworth Road]], [[South London]], the same year.{{cite web |url=http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/help/aboutus.aspx |title=About Us |publisher=Blockbuster UK |accessdate=January 16, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115221240/http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/Help/aboutus.aspx |archivedate=January 15, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://business.highbeam.com/4524/article-1G1-11849744/blockbuster-uk-division-buys-ritz-video-rental-chain|title=Blockbuster's U.K. division buys Ritz Video rental chain. (Blockbuster Entertainment) (Brief Article)|date=February 17, 1992|work=Highbeam Business|accessdate=March 29, 2013}} By November 1991, Blockbuster UK converted 30 stores to its brand. Blockbuster UK operated trade functions in all their stores, buying and selling pre-owned DVDs, console games, and gaming accessories. Stores offered either store credit or cash for trade-ins, and would price-match with competitors. In early 2013, the company had 528 locations in the United Kingdom. On January 16, 2013, Blockbuster placed its United Kingdom subsidiaries in [[Administration (law)|administration]], putting over 4,000 jobs at risk. Non-UK stores were unaffected by the administration, and continued to trade as normal. On February 1, 2013, a large number of Blockbuster stores in the UK were closed, and the UK business was purchased out of administration by restructuring firm [[Gordon Brothers Group|Gordon Brothers Europe]] on March 23, 2013.{{cite news |title=Buyer found for Blockbuster stores, say administrators |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21912508 |newspaper=BBC News |date=March 23, 2013 |accessdate=March 22, 2013}} Blockbuster UK then traded as ''TS Operations'', with only 264 branches retained. On October 29, 2013, Blockbuster UK announced it was to go into administration for a second time.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-24730726 |title=Blockbuster back in administration |publisher=BBC News |date=October 29, 2013 |accessdate=October 29, 2013}} On November 14, 2013, 72 store closures were announced,{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-24938668 | work=BBC News | title=Blockbuster's administrator will close 72 stores | date=November 14, 2013}} with another 62 made on December 5.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-25232069 | work=BBC News | title=Blockbuster to close more stores as 427 more jobs go | date=December 5, 2013}} A week later, with no success in finding a buyer, it was announced by ''Moorfields Corporate Recovery'' that all remaining stores in the country would cease operation on December 16, 2013, with stock cleared the day before.{{cite news|title=Blockbuster to close remaining stores|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-25345257|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=December 13, 2013|date=December 12, 2013}} Following ''[[Deadpool 2]]'''s digital release, a [[pop-up retail]] store in the style of the original 1989 Blockbuster outlets is set to arrive to [[Shoreditch]]. The store will be giving away 1,989 copies of the film as a reference to Blockbuster's entry year into the British market. Additionally, those with an original membership card can skip the queue and get their copies of the film before others. It was set to operate on the 16th and 17th of September, 2018.[https://londonist.com/london/film/blockbuster-reopens-london-deadpool "Blockbuster Video Reopens In London... Well, For Two Days Anyway"], Londonist, 12 September 2018 ==Online rentals== ===United States=== In 1997, [[Enron Corporation]] had entered the broadband market, constructing and purchasing thousands of miles of fiber optic cables throughout the United States.{{cite news|last1=Schiesel|first1=Seth|title=Jumping Off the Bandwidth Wagon|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/07/11/business/jumping-off-the-bandwidth-wagon.html|accessdate=17 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 July 1999}}{{cite news|title=Montana Power, Williams Communications, Enron Units Announce Fiber Providers for Portland-to-Los Angeles Network|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/montana-power-williams-communications-enron-units-announce-fiber-providers-for-portland-to-los-angeles-network-77921802.html|accessdate=17 February 2017|work=[[PRNewswire]]|date=17 December 1997|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217071349/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/montana-power-williams-communications-enron-units-announce-fiber-providers-for-portland-to-los-angeles-network-77921802.html|archive-date=February 17, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In 2001, Enron and Blockbuster Inc. attempted to create a 20-year deal to stream [[Video on demand|movies on demand]] over Enron's fiber optic network.{{cite news|last1=Behr|first1=Peter|title=Broadband Strategy Got Enron in Trouble; Bid to Create Market for Fiber-Optic Space Included Aggressive Accounting|work=[[The Washington Post]]|issue=E01|date=1 January 2001}} However, the "heavily promoted" deal fell through, with Enron's shares dropping following the announcement. On August 11, 2004, Blockbuster introduced a [[DVD-by-mail]] service in the U.S. to compete with the established market leader, [[Netflix]].[http://money.cnn.com/2004/08/11/technology/blockbuster_rental/ Blockbuster going after NetFlix] CNNMoney. August 11, 2004. Retrieved July 25, 2013. Blockbuster's U.S. online operation started with around 10 warehouses; further expansions every year brought that number to 41, plus more than 1400 stores in the Blockbuster Online network. Most Blockbuster independent franchises did not honor the Total Access program. The company had 1.5 million subscribers at the end of the third quarter of 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6387895.html |title=Blockbuster reports narrowed Q3 loss |publisher=Video Business |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=June 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216082434/http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6387895.html |archivedate=February 16, 2009 }} Blockbuster's move to follow the business pattern with its online rentals as was established by Netflix prompted Netflix to sue Blockbuster for patent infringement. Blockbuster counter sued with a counterclaim alleging deceptive practices with its patent which it alleged was designed to maintain an illegal monopoly. The suits were eventually settled, and while the terms were not disclosed it was later reported that Netflix recorded a settlement payment from Blockbuster of $4.1 million in the second quarter of 2007.{{cite news|last=Associated |first=The |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/24/technology/24netflix.html |title=NetFlix Outlook Gloomy Despite A Profitable Quarter |work=The New York Times |date=July 24, 2007 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} Blockbuster offered several online movie rental plans. In some cities customers could add games to their movie rental queue as if they were included in their plan, but game rentals resulted in a separate additional fee which was not displayed or charged until the end of the billing cycle.http://blockbuster3.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/1497/kw/game%20rental/r_id/106342{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Until July 26, 2007, Blockbuster offered and advertised unlimited free in-store exchanges of online rentals with all plans. Since then there were several changes back and forth with regard to this policy; as of March 2010 customers were allowed a limited number of in-store exchanges. At the end of 2006, Blockbuster Total Access had 2.2 million customers, exceeding their original goal of 2 million, according to its website.{{cite press release |url=http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=706 |title=Blockbuster Achieves Year-End Goal of 2 Million Online Subscribers |publisher=Blockbuster MediaRoom |location=DALLAS |date=January 3, 2007 |accessdate=January 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201174903/http://blockbuster.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=706 |archivedate=December 1, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} After an aggressive media campaign that accounted for much of Blockbuster's $46.4 million net loss in the first quarter of 2007, the Total Access subscriber base surpassed 3 million customers in total, marking the company's highest subscriber growth quarter ever.{{cite press release |url=http://www.b2i.us/profiles/investor/ResLibraryView.asp?BzID=553&ResLibraryID=19771&Category=1027 |title=Blockbuster Reports First quarter 2007 Results |publisher=Blockbuster Inc. |date=May 2, 2007 |accessdate=January 28, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} By 2009, however, the company was declining to provide figures when asked by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.{{cite news|last=Mcbride |first=Sarah |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125303731573912777 |title=Wall Street Journal, "Blockbuster to Shutter More Stores" |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=September 16, 2009 |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} On January 5, 2007, Southern Stores Inc., one of Blockbuster's largest franchise operators in the United States, filed a lawsuit in federal court alleging that, by introducing Blockbuster Online and Blockbuster Total Access, the rental chain has undercut the group's franchise agreement.{{cite web|url=http://www.memphisdailynews.com/Editorial/StoryFocus.aspx?&id=95692 |title=Blockbusted! Local franchisee sues Blockbuster Inc., alleges Dallas company 'undercut' its business – 1/5/2007 |work=Memphis Daily News |accessdate=June 16, 2011}} On August 6, 2010, Blockbuster By Mail subscribers gained access to Blockbuster's library of console games, in addition to movies and television shows. On March 31, 2012, Blockbuster On Demand removed support from set-top box media players, including [[Vudu]], [[Western Digital Media Center|WDTV]], and [[Roku]]. Supported devices now only include computers, Blu-ray players, select television sets, and cellular phones.{{cite web|url=http://wdc.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/9391/p/208,393/session/L3RpbWUvMTM0MDA1NzI3OS9zaWQvX2VQTURfLWs%3D |title=Accessing the Blockbuster On Demand service on a WD TV Live Product |publisher=Wdc.custhelp.com |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=November 7, 2013}} On February 26, 2013, [[Roku, Inc.]] announced that Blockbuster On Demand was being launched on Roku's channel store. Supported devices now include computers, Blu-ray players, select television sets, cellular phones, and the Roku set-top box.{{cite web|url=http://blog.roku.com/blog/2013/02/26/blockbuster-on-demand-launches-on-roku/ |title=Blockbuster On Demand launches on Roku | The Official Roku Blog |publisher=|date=February 26, 2013 |accessdate=November 7, 2013}} In November 2013, Dish Network said its DVD-by-mail service would shut down by mid-December.{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2013/11/06/blockbuster-closing/3456271/ | title=Blockbuster to close U.S. retail stores, mail DVD operation | work=[[USA Today]] | date=November 6, 2013 | accessdate=November 7, 2013 | first1=Roger | last1=Yu}} As of 2015, Blockbuster on Demand is part of Dish Network's Sling TV product and no longer exists as a standalone service.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sling.com/blockbuster|title=Sling - Blockbuster|website=www.sling.com|access-date=2017-06-16}} ===United Kingdom=== [[File:"BLOCKBUSTER" video shop, Northwood - geograph.org.uk - 976027.jpg|thumb|right|A former Blockbuster store]]Rentals cost £3.50 to £4.50 and lasted for five nights, usually from Monday to Friday due to the postal service. Late fees of £0.70 to £0.90 per disc applied if a disc was not returned on time.{{cite web |url=http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/Help/PayPerRentQuickStart.aspx |title=Help – Pay Per Rent Quick Start Guide |publisher=Blockbuster UK |accessdate=June 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720023158/http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/Help/PayPerRentQuickStart.aspx |archivedate=July 20, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} In May 2004, Blockbuster also introduced a conventional online subscription service. The unlimited three-disc plan costs £14.99/month but does not allow in-store exchange, contrary to the U.S. service. Partial support for in-store exchange would not be added until April 2005 with the launch of an "OnlineXtra" service. This service cost £2 per month, required an online subscription to a disc plan, and added two extra discs sent by mail. The OnlineXtra discs could be exchanged in store, but the non-OnlineXtra discs could not. The program was discontinued in 2006 with no [[Grandfather clause|grandfathering]], but an in-store-only variant of it resurfaced in early 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/bandsignup/all-rental-plans.aspx |title=Band Signup – All Rental Plans |publisher=Blockbuster UK |accessdate=June 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628224148/http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/bandsignup/all-rental-plans.aspx |archivedate=June 28, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} A "Click & Collect" service launched in September 2010 allows the reservation of Blockbuster movies in store, but the store's regular rental fees applied until the company added in-store exchanged in May 2012.{{cite web |url=http://blog.blockbuster.co.uk/2010/09/the-new-way-to-rent-click-collect/ |title=The new way to rent – Click & Collect |publisher=Blockbuster UK |accessdate=June 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017014151/http://blog.blockbuster.co.uk/2010/09/the-new-way-to-rent-click-collect |archivedate=October 17, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://blog.blockbuster.co.uk/2012/05/service-update-introducing-in-store-exchange-total-access/ |title=Service Update – Introducing In-Store Exchange / Total Access |publisher=Blockbuster UK |df=mdy-all }} On January 16, 2013, Blockbuster UK entered [[Administration (law)|administration]], appointing [[Deloitte]] as company administrators, casting doubt over the future of their 528 stores in the country.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21047652 |title=Blockbuster goes into administration Blockbuster said that it was shutting 129 of its 528 stores in the UK |publisher=BBC News|date=January 16, 2012}} An announcement was then made by Deloitte that 160 UK stores would close. On February 13, 2013 Deloitte announced a further 164 stores closures, leaving 204 stores trading in the UK. The business was sold to restructuring firm the [[Gordon Brothers Group]] on March 23, 2013. On October 29, 2013, Gordon Brothers filed notice of intention to appoint an administrator. On November 28, 2013, Blockbuster UK officially entered administration for the second time, and by December 2013, all stores were closed, as no buyer for the chain was found. ===Brazil=== In January 2006, Blockbuster Brazil also introduced an online rental service now featuring both DVD and Blu-ray plans. There were four Block plans available with prices ranging from R$34.90 to R$79.90. The 3-disc plan with unlimited exchanges was R$49.90/month. Unlike the U.S. service, there was no in-store disk exchange.[http://www.blockbuster.com.br Blockbuster Brazil]. Retrieved October 25, 2012. {{failed verification|date=October 2012}}{{failed verification|date=October 2012}} ===Movielink acquisition=== On August 8, 2007, Blockbuster announced that it reached an agreement to purchase [[Movielink]]. According to the [[8-K]] filing by Blockbuster, the total purchase price was $6.6 million. === Rejection of Netflix purchase offer === In 2000, [[Reed Hastings]], the founder of [[Netflix]], approached Blockbuster with an offer to sell his company to Blockbuster for US$50 million. John Antioco, the Blockbuster CEO, was not interested in the offer because he thought it was a "very small niche business" and it was losing money at the time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/blockbuster-ceo-passed-up-chance-to-buy-netflix-for-50-million-2015-7?r=US&IR=T |title=Blockbuster's CEO once passed up a chance to buy Netflix for only $50 million|last=Chong|first=Celena|date=2015-07-18|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=2017-05-27|language=en}} ==Advertising== ===Super Bowl=== One of Blockbuster's most well known [[advertising campaign]]s was launched during the 2002 [[Super Bowl]]. It starred the voices of [[Jim Belushi]] and [[James Woods]], as a rabbit and a [[guinea pig]] in a pet shop, located across the road from a Blockbuster store. The first campaign ended in 2003. The Carl and Ray campaign started again in 2007 starting with a commercial in the first quarter of [[Super Bowl XLI]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/16996195/ns/business-us_business/t/best-super-bowl-ad-readers-pick-blockbuster/#.VG8aOItvwX4 |title=Best Super Bowl ad? Readers pick a Blockbuster |last1=Neill |first1=Rob |date=February 5, 2007 |work=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=November 21, 2014}} ===Misleading advertising=== In 2005, Blockbuster launched a marketing campaign describing changes in its late fees policy and offering "No Late Fees" on rentals. The program sparked investigations and charges of misrepresentation in 48 states and the District of Columbia, as state attorneys general including [[Bill Lockyer]] of California, [[Greg Abbott]] of Texas, and [[Eliot Spitzer]] of New York argued that customers were being automatically charged the full purchase price of late rentals and a restocking fee for rentals returned after 30 days. In a settlement, Blockbuster agreed to reimburse the states the cost of their investigation, clarify communication to customers on the terms of the program, and offer reimbursement to customers charged fees prior to the clarification. New Jersey filed a separate lawsuit and was not a party to the settlement.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/02/18/entertainment/main675086.shtml |publisher=CBS News |date=February 18, 2005 |title=Blockbuster Sued Over Late Fees}}{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/7327309/ |publisher=MSNBC |date=March 30, 2005 |title=Blockbuster settles "no late fees" claims}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A36767-2005Feb18.html |work=The Washington Post |title=Blockbuster sued over return policy |date=February 19, 2005 |author=Caroline Mayer }}{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/advertising/adtrack/2005-02-27-track_x.htm |author=Michael McCarthy |date=February 27, 2005 |work=[[USA Today]] |title='No late fees' ads cause a stir}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/mar/30/business/fi-blockbuster30 |work=The Los Angeles Times |date=March 30, 2005 |author=Lorenza Munoz |title=Blockbuster Settles State Probes Into Late Fee Ads }} The 2005 controversy came after a related lawsuit settled in 2002 in Texas. That lawsuit, alleging exorbitant late fees, led the company to pay $9.25 million in attorney fees and offer $450 million in late fee refund coupons (which were rent-one get-one-free coupons, and thus required the customer to make an initial expenditure). The company estimated that the coupons would ultimately cost about $45 million depending on the redemption rate; an attorney for the plaintiffs estimated the final cost at closer to $100 million at a redemption rate of about 20% (calculated based on a similar case in Michigan).{{cite web |url=http://www.courant.com/topic/sns-blockbuster,0,5496993.story |date=June 6, 2001 |author=Sarah Hale |publisher=The Los Angeles Times, via the Hartford Courant |title=Blockbuster to settle lawsuit over late fees}}{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,42827,00.html |publisher=Fox News |date=January 11, 2002 |title=Blockbuster customers to be reimbursed for late fees}} Such corrections were also sent to international stores such as those in Canada to prevent further lawsuits. Blockbuster reintroduced late fees in the United States in 2010 under the name of "Additional Daily Rates". With this pricing scheme, rentals were once again limited to a certain number of days and accrued pay-per-day rates after the days allocated are exceeded. ==Senior management history== * John F. Antioco, CEO: 1997–2007 * James W. Keyes, CEO: 2007–2011 * Kevin Lewis, senior vice president and chief marketing officer: 2008–2012{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/kevinalewis|title=Kevin Lewis LinkedIn Page|publisher=|accessdate=July 13, 2018}} * Dennis McGill, executive vice president and chief financial officer: 2010–2013{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/markets/stocks|title=Stocks|publisher=|accessdate=December 17, 2016}} * Michael Kelly, president: 2011–2015{{cite web|url=http://about.dish.com/press-release/veteran-dish-executive-michael-kelly-announces-retirement|title=Veteran DISH Executive Michael Kelly announces retirement - About DISH|publisher=|accessdate=December 17, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220094235/http://about.dish.com/press-release/veteran-dish-executive-michael-kelly-announces-retirement|archive-date=December 20, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==See also== * [[Hollywood Video]] * [[Family Video]] * [[Movie Gallery]] * [[Netflix]] * [[Dish Network]] {{Portal bar|Dallas-Fort Worth|Miami|Companies}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Blockbuster}} * {{official website|http://www.blockbuster.com}} {{Video rental shops}} {{Video digital distribution platforms}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Blockbuster LLC]] [[Category:Franchises]] [[Category:Home video companies of the United States]] [[Category:Video rental services]] [[Category:Defunct retail companies of the United States]] [[Category:Defunct retail companies of Canada]] [[Category:Defunct companies based in Texas]] [[Category:Companies based in McKinney, Texas]] [[Category:American companies established in 1985]] [[Category:Canadian companies established in 1990]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1985]] [[Category:Retail companies disestablished in 2014]] [[Category:2014 disestablishments in Canada]] [[Category:Companies delisted from the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Companies that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2010]] [[Category:Companies that have entered administration in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Dish Network]] [[Category:Former Viacom subsidiaries]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Born Free | image = | director = [[Romain Gavras]] | producer = | eproducer = | aproducer = | writer = [[Maya Arulpragasam]] (creator) | starring = Ian Hamrick | music = Maya "M.I.A." Arulpragasam | cinematography = Andre Chemetoff | editing = | distributor = [[XL Recordings]]
[[Interscope Geffen A&M Records|Interscope Geffen A&M]] | released = 26 April 2010 (premiere) | runtime = 9:06 | country = United States | language = English | budget = $250,000 (estimated) }} The [[music video]] for English recording artist [[M.I.A. (artist)|M.I.A.]]'s "[[Born Free (M.I.A. song)|Born Free]]" was directed by [[Romain Gavras]]. The video, which depicts a [[genocide]] against [[red hair|red haired people]], was filmed in [[California]] and directed by [[Romain Gavras]] as a nine-minute short film without the prior knowledge of M.I.A.'s record labels. Several incidents relating to the extra-judicial killing of [[Tamil people|Tamil]] males by the [[Sri Lanka's Killing Fields|Sri Lankan Army filmed on mobile phones in Sri Lanka]], some of which had been broadcast by news outlets worldwide, inspired M.I.A.'s [[film treatment|treatment]] for the film-video. The video's portrayal of military force, violence and brutality met with a positive critical reception but much controversy worldwide, including a ban from YouTube in the US and UK. Some critics hailed its representation of oppression and political turmoil, while others criticized the more explicit material. The way the film was shot and the themes it covered drew comparisons to previous works by the artist, and other writer-directors' films such as ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' and ''[[Punishment Park]]''. It earned a nomination for "Best Dance Video" at the 2010 [[UK Music Video Awards]]. ==Development== The music video-short film, filmed in [[Los Angeles]] and [[Lancaster, California]] on 15 January 2010 was written by M.I.A. and directed by French director [[Romain Gavras]].{{Cite journal|author=Mackay, Emily|url=|title=MIA interview|publisher=[[NME]]|page=26|date=16 January 2010}} Gavras, who directed the video for the song "Stress" by [[Justice (band)|Justice]] which proved controversial after release dealt with themes of "real and fake" which complimented M.I.A.'s vision for the video. M.I.A. intended for the video to depict something real "made not real" to reach a wider audience. The video would depict the footage of the extra-judicial killing of Tamil males she had uploaded three months prior onto her Twitter feed.{{Cite episode|credits=Stroumboulopoulos, George (Interviewer), M.I.A. (Interviewee)|title=M.I.A.|series=[[George Stroumboulopoulos Tonight|The Hour]]|network= [[CBC Television]]|medium=TV-Series|location=[[Toronto]], Canada|minutes=9:04|airdate=15 January 2011}} Red haired men were used in the video following teasing of ''[[Maya (M.I.A. album)|Maya]]'' collaborator [[Rusko (musician)|Rusko]] in the studio during the album's recording. The songwriter stated it was one of those "ideas where people would beat the shit out of me because I was ginger [a natural redhead]. It has a whole double meaning. The gingers are kind of anyone who’s been oppressed...I didn't think she'd actually do it."{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/posts/mias-producer-says-born-free-video-new-album-will-scare-people |title=M.I.A. Producer: 'Born Free' Video Started As Joke; New Album Will 'Scare People' |publisher=VIBE |date=2010-04-28 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} Other roles in the video are played by veterans from the [[U.S. Army]] returning from wars in Afghanistan and Iraq; the video also features fake blood and ketchup imported from [[China]].{{cite episode|series=[[Q (radio show)|Q]]|credits=[[Jian Ghomeshi]] (Interviewer), M.I.A. (Interviewee)|url=http://www.cbc.ca/q/blog/2010/10/18/mia-uncut/|title=M.I.A. Uncut|network=[[CBC Radio]] |location=Toronto, Canada|date=18 October 2010|accessdate=12 January 2011}} Gavras went on to direct the film ''[[Our Day Will Come (film)|Our Day Will Come]]'', a continuation of the ginger-genocide theme of the video-short. ==Synopsis== [[File:Flickr - moses namkung - M.I.A. 1.jpg|thumb|left|200px| M.I.A.'s dancer "WhyteBoi" from the [[Maya Tour|/\/\/\Y/\ Tour]] appears in the film.]] The film is over nine minutes long and depicts a [[SWAT team]] driving up to a building and staging a raid, during which they ignore a man sitting in a room smoking a crack pipe, beat a couple engaged in coitus, and then force a young [[Red hair|red-haired]] man violently into a detainee transport vehicle. Other red-heads are rounded up. Some of the SWAT team members wear American flags on their uniforms. During the video, a mural is seen depicting armed red-headed men and the slogan "Our day will come", the historic motto of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|Irish Republican Army]] (''[[Tiocfaidh ár lá]]''). [[Keffiya]]-wearing red-haired young people throw rocks and glass bottles at the armored vehicles transporting the detainees, in an apparent reference to the iconic images of the Second Palestinian "[[Second Intifada|Intifada]]".{{cite web|last=Galil |first=Leor |url=http://trueslant.com/leorgalil/2010/04/26/finding-meaning-in-m-i-a-s-born-free-video/ |title=Finding meaning in M.I.A.’s ‘Born Free’ video - Leor Galil - Ex-Spectator |publisher=True/Slant |date=2010-04-26 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} The detainees are then driven out to the desert, treated brutally, and forced to run across a live [[minefield]].James Montgomery (26 April 2010). [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1637769/20100426/mia__4_.jhtml M.I.A. Releases Brutally Graphic Video for 'Born Free']. [[MTV]]. Retrieved 27 April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/38604-watch-the-extremely-nsfw-mia-video/|title=Watch the Extremely NSFW M.I.A. Video| author=Amy Phillips|publisher=Pitchfork Media|accessdate=26 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/mia/50823|title=MIA releases violent video for new song 'Born Free'|publisher=[[NME]]|accessdate=26 April 2010}} During the course of events, a young red-headed boy is shot through the head, and another is blown to pieces after stepping on a live mine while the soldiers continue to chase, beat, and shoot the captives. The "Born Free" film includes graphic violence and language, as well as nudity. Ian Hamrick, the 12-year-old red-haired actor whose character is shot in the head in the film, described the video as "showing violence to end violence." He felt a potency in the video absent from far more graphic video game media such as ''[[Call of Duty]]'' or ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/mia/50911 |title=Child 'killed' in MIA's 'Born Free' video defends singer |date=30 April 2010 |publisher=NME |accessdate=16 July 2010}}{{cite news| author=Brown, August|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2010/05/twelveyearold-ian-hamrick-on-his-gruesome-death-in-mias-born-free-video.html | title=Twelve-year-old Ian Hamrick on his gruesome death in M.I.A.'s 'Born Free' video|work=Los Angeles Times | series=Pop & Hiss blog|date=10 May 2010|accessdate=18 October 2011}} Giving more details on his role in an interview to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', Hamrick said M.I.A. complimented his work on set, stating "She wanted to make sure I was OK, that I knew what was happening and why she killed [my character]. I said I did, that she really accomplished her goal of getting people to talk about something they don’t usually see." ==Release and critical response== [[File:Lancaster, California desert.jpg|thumb|right|210px|The music video was partly filmed at the [[Lancaster, California]] desert, imaged above]] On 26 April 2010, the music video was released online and was immediately noted as political allegory, drawing parallels to genocides and many indigenous resistance movements around the world.[http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/music/823394-m-i-a-releases-controversial-born-free-music-video M.I.A. releases controversial Born Free music video]. [[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]. 27 April 2010. Retrieved 27 April 2010. Its content elicited strong, widespread discussion across the world. Real life parallels were drawn with the issue of immigration in the American state of Arizona, the treatment of [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse|prisoners by U.S. troops at the Abu Ghraib prison]] in [[Baghdad]], and, more universally, the brutal tactics used against minorities by government forces around the world. ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' stated "Whether it's a comment on the absurdity of [[genocide]] (of which M.I.A. saw plenty during her early childhood in [[Sri Lanka]]) or a challenge to the idea of "other" in [[Arizona SB1070|Arizona's immigration law]], it is startling even in the context of recent genre-bending music art-films."[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/26/mia-releases-graphic-expl_n_552486.html M.I.A. Releases Graphic, Explicit 'Born Free' Video (NSFW)]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. 26 April 2010. Retrieved 26 April 2010. Zach Baron, writing in ''[[The Village Voice]]'' added "[[NSFW]] isn't exactly the word. More like art film? We can think of no goofier political allegory than the persecution, abuse, and murder of redheads, but then again, M.I.A.'s politics have never been of the kind you read about in the ''New York Times''."Zach Baron (26 April 2010). [http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/archives/2010/04/mias_born_free.php M.I.A.'s "Born Free" Video: Police Brutality, Mass Redhead Genocide, and Exploding Humans] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100429142759/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/archives/2010/04/mias_born_free.php# |date=29 April 2010 }}. The Village Voice. Retrieved 31 July 2010. James Montgomery of ''[[MTV]]'' described it as "unflinchingly, unapologetically real" depicting "the kind of things that most nations — including the U.S., which is portrayed as the aggressor in the clip — often pretend don't happen: the rounding-up of ethnic minorities, the trampling of personal liberties, the bullying of the powerless by those with authority." [[Ann Powers]] wrote in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' that the video "concentrated fully" on the physical horror of gun butts and bullets hitting flesh, with the scenes giving added poignancy to the lyrical themes of the song.{{Cite news|author=Powers, Ann| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2010/04/mia-makes-her-stance-utterly-clear-with-born-free-video-1.html |title=M.I.A. makes her stance utterly clear with 'Born Free' video |work=Los Angeles Times |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2010}} Interpreted as a comment on desensitised attitudes towards violence, others found that the video stressed that genocide still exists and violent repression remains commonplace.Douglas Haddow (1 May 2010). [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/may/01/mia-video-real-controversy The real controversy of MIA's video] [[The Guardian]]. Retrieved 31 July 2010. Some critics described the film as "sensationalist". [[Neda Ulaby]] of [[NPR]] described the video as intended for "shock value" in the service of nudging people into considering real issues that can be hard to talk about.{{Cite news|author=MTV Newsroom|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/06/22/mia-born-free-controversy/|publisher=MTV|title=M.I.A. Learned From The 'Born Free' Controversy'|date=22 June 2010|accessdate=1 November 2010}}{{Cite news | author=Cochrane, Lauren | title=Romain Gavras: Born Free director is no stranger to Stress | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/sep/25/romain-gavras-born-free |work=The Guardian |location=UK |publisher=Guardian Media Group | date=25 September 2010 | accessdate=7 October 2010 }}{{cite web|author=[[Neda Ulaby|Ulaby, Neda]]|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=127239101 |title=From Elvis To Lady Gaga: Playing With Shock Value In Music |publisher=[[NPR]] |date= |accessdate=12 August 2010}} Haddow wrote further in ''The Guardian'' that particularly notable about the video was its use of red headed individuals as a proxy for anyone who has felt the brunt of a jackboot. The effect of this was that the viewer was "expected to empathise with the victim, rather than the aggressor." Haddow stated that this sat in "stark contrast" to the bulk of recent films on the subject of the Afghan and Iraq wars such as [[Katheryn Bigelow]]'s ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' (2009), [[Oren Moverman]]'s ''[[The Messenger (2009 film)|The Messenger]]'' (2009) and ''[[Green Zone (film)|Green Zone]]'' (2010) written by [[Brian Helgeland]] and directed by [[Paul Greengrass]], where focus was almost entirely on the psychological experiences of military personnel, continuing "Rarely do we ever catch a glimpse of the locals, whom we are supposed to be helping, unless they are being blown up or used as plot devices to heighten the suspense." Other critics also pointed to differences between "Born Free" and Bigelow's ''The Hurt Locker'' but similarities between the video and [[Peter Watkins]]' ''[[Punishment Park]]'' (1971). ''[[Salon.com|Salon]]'' described "Born Free" as the most violent music video made in a long time and called it a nine-minute masterpiece, adding that "M.I.A. has built a career on making music that's as outspoken as it is danceable" and described the video as "undeniably powerful, a lurid parable on the systematic [[ethnic cleansing]] that goes on all over the world." Mary Elizabeth Williams (27 April 2010). [http://www.salon.com/news/music/index.html?story=/mwt/feature/2010/04/27/mia_born_free_video Does M.I.A.'s genocide video go too far?]. [[Salon.com|Salon]]. Retrieved 31 July 2010. Eric Henderson in ''[[Slant (magazine)|Slant]]'' stated "what stuck with me is the furious dignity it accords the main tracksuit-wearing prisoner, and the amount of anger it allows him to deliver....I recognized within him and the band of rock-throwing dissidents that pelt the armored bus a sense of kinship relevant to anyone who occupies a minority class." While he felt that "the clip is but a metaphor, and not entirely successfully so, when the pitbull-faced, tenement-snatched redhead boy is slammed against an iron fence and still dares to glare into the eyes of his attackers, I want to be right there by his side fucking their shit up."Eric Henderson (29 April 2010). [http://www.slantmagazine.com/house/2010/04/music-video-m-i-a-s-born-free/ Music Video: M.I.A.'s "Born Free"]. Slant Magazine. Retrieved 29 April 2010. ==Aftermath== [[RT America]] (a [[Russia]]n television network) producer Lucy Kafanov noted how several mainstream American TV news networks hesitated in covering the reaction to the video initially despite the widespread response. She said this was in contrast to their coverage of the controversy of [[Erykah Badu]]'s "[[Window Seat (song)|Window Seat]]" video two weeks prior, and suggested this was because the video for "Born Free" "hit too close to home" in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5K8GoDXXUoY |title=M.I.A. music video banned from |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-04-27 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' writer Monica Herrera stated that anyone who was "up in arms" over Badu's video would probably feel "ridiculous" after watching the video for "Born Free".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/viral-videos/958476/mias-born-free-video-banned-from-youtube-for-graphic-violence |title=M.I.A.'s 'Born Free' Video Banned from YouTube for Graphic Violence - Viral Videos |publisher=Billboard.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-22}} Journalist [[Alyona Minkovski]] of ''[[The Alyona Show]]'' noted how M.I.A.'s own experiences with genocide in Sri Lanka contributed to the themes in the video but that the silence of the artist left audience members to speculate on several connections between the video and real events. [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] rapper [[Narcy (rapper)|Narcy]], [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] hip hop group [[DAM (band)|DAM]] and singer Sabreena Da Witch told MTV Iggy that they saw the video as a "grander metaphor for society" and persecution in areas of political turmoil.{{cite web|last=Quinlan |first=Adriane |url=http://www.mtviggy.com/blog-posts/arab-rappers-weigh-in-on-m-i-a-s-born-free-video/ |title=Arab Rappers Weigh In On M.I.A.’s "Born Free" Video |publisher=Mtv Iggy |date=2010-04-30 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} The British network [[Sky News]] reported that Sherry Adhami, spokeswoman for the UK [[Beatbullying]] charity found the video "inappropriate" as it could "lead to more abuse against red-haired people." Caroline Sullivan of ''The Guardian'' told the network "I think M.I.A. is making the point that if we segregated all ginger people as a minority - in the same way as black and Asian people - there would be an enormous outcry, and that we don't seem to get the same reaction when black people are treated in this way." She also stated that M.I.A. depicted violence in order to make a political point, in a way different from [[gangsta rap]].{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/home/showbiz-news/article/15623553 |title=M.I.A.: 'Ginger Genocide' Music Video Born Free Slammed By Bullying Charity, Defended By Actor | Showbiz News | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-22}} Hamrick was to be prominently featured in the video for "[[Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)]]" by [[Shakira]] and [[Freshlyground]], the official [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] anthem but his appearance was allegedly recut to a crowd scene following the "Born Free" video release. "Waka Waka"'s producers responded that Hamrick was always meant to be an extra in the video and that this was not due to the controversy. Hamrick said of "Born Free" that he was really "proud to be a part of M.I.A.’s shout-out to the world" because "it was a great chance to tell everyone that bully’s [sic] suck no matter what country you are from."{{cite web|last=Paskin |first=Willa |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/05/shakira_video_snubs_red_head_w.html |title=Shakira Video Snubs Redhead Who Got Shot in the Head in M.I.A. Video - Vulture |publisher=Nymag.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-22}}{{cite web|last=Baron |first=Zach |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2010/05/getting_child-m.php |title=Getting Child-Murdered In An M.I.A. Video May Not Be the Best Career Decision, It Turns Out - New York Music - Sound of the City |publisher=Blogs.villagevoice.com |date=2010-05-04 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} Gavras was more reassured that audiences talked about the subject by themselves, than explaining the video himself as the debate over the video heightened, although he questioned "How can you be shocked by the M.I.A. video and not shocked when [[Israel]] bombs [[Gaza City|Gaza]] for days and days...Really crazy stuff where people actually die, real things." [[Vincent Cassel]], star of Gavras' film ''Our Day Will Come'', stated he found the video "scary, shocking and totally crazy" on the first viewing, and added "If it would have been with any kind of community it would have been terrible, but suddenly it's redheads, so it's like a symbol of a quest that doesn't really exist." Thus the video also seemed "strange and funny" to him.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a332376/mia-born-free-video-was-shocking-and-funny-says-vincent-cassel.html |title=MIA 'Born Free' video was shocking and funny, says Vincent Cassel - Music News |publisher=Digital Spy |date=2011-08-01 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} M.I.A. stated in an interview to MTV News that she found the reaction to the film "fascinating" but that she was baffled by the media's fixation on the clip when real issues were ignored, stating "I think it's interesting how we react to fiction and how we react to realism on the internet... this is mainstream media, I wish I was talking about way more underground theories, but [I'm] not, this is just me digesting what I see in the mainstream."{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a231806/mia-fascinated-by-born-free-reaction.html |title=M.I.A. 'fascinated by Born Free reaction' - Music News |publisher=Digital Spy |date=2010-06-23 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} She joked to NME that she found the new [[Justin Bieber]] video "more of an assault to my eyes and senses than what I've made".{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/7712177/MIA-plays-down-controversy-over-execution-video.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=MIA plays down controversy over execution video | date=12 May 2010}} A few weeks later, in an interview with [[Angie Martinez]] of [[WQHT|Hot 97]] radio station in New York City, she said "I said I love Justin Bieber and everyone like went crazy. It's weird. No I said that I found his video offensive, because people said they found my video offensive [...] It got out of hand, Now I feel really bad coz I have some family members who love Justin Bieber, and now they won't talk to me, I need my little cousins to talk to me!"{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VXVttROems4 |title=Mia Hot 97 |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-06-25 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} A week after its release on [[Vimeo]] on 26 April, the video was viewed 1.8 million times on the site. From 27 April to 2 May, M.I.A. remained the most blogged about artist on the internet, according to MP3 blog aggregator [[The Hype Machine]].[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/most-blogged-artists-mia-the-xx-jamaica-1955809.html Most blogged artists: M.I.A., The xx, Jamaica]. The Independent. 27 April 2010. Retrieved 31 July 2010.[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/most-blogged-artists-sleigh-bells-kelis-the-books-1961247.html Most blogged artists: Sleigh Bells, Kelis, The Books]. The Independent. 3 May 2010. Retrieved 31 July 2010. The video was then re-posted on YouTube by [[VEVO]], without users having to sign in to prove they were 18 or older. The raw video is also on M.I.A.'s website. The video has been viewed over 30 million times on the internet.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/pda/2010/apr/28/mia-bornfree-youtube | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Jemima | last=Kiss | title=MIA's redheads video gets a wrist-slap from YouTube – and coverage in China | date=28 April 2010}} ==YouTube controversy and response== Video sharing website [[YouTube]] removed the film from viewing in the United States within a day of its posting. Some other uploads of the video were subsequently age-gated on the site, while others were removed due to copyright claims. YouTube stated that they did not comment on individual clips on the site but said that videos were removed only after users reported videos that could "contravene guidelines." Commentators proposed different reasons for the actions, from the graphic "excessive" violence depicted to political censorship. On 27 April, the [[BBC]] reported that the video was being removed in some instances by YouTube, and labelled with an age-restriction in others. Neither M.I.A. or her record label [[XL Recordings]] commented on the development in the weeks following the release.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/hi/music/newsid_10080000/newsid_10087800/10087809.stm M.I.A video 'removed by YouTube']. BBC. 27 April 2010. Retrieved 27 April 2010. Lisa Respers France wrote in [[CNN]] that the YouTube block may have worked in M.I.A.'s favor as it brought more publicity.{{cite news| url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-04-27/entertainment/mia.music.video_1_mia-music-video-nine-minute-video%3F_s%3DPM:SHOWBIZ | work=CNN | title=M.I.A. music video elicits strong online response | date=2 June 2009}} M.I.A. tweeted she initially suspected her US parent label [[Universal Music Group]] to be responsible but confirmed it was not soon after.Maya Arulpragasam. [https://twitter.com/_M_I_A_/status/12876928077 Twitter / maya arulpragasam]. [[Twitter]]. Retrieved 23 July 2010. The singer-rapper stated that she found YouTube's action on the video "ridiculous", citing YouTube's streaming of real-life killings.{{Cite news|last=Sawyer|first=Miranda|title=MIA: 'I'm here for the people'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jun/13/mia-feature-miranda-sawyer|accessdate=23 July 2010|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=13 June 2010 | location=London}}{{Cite magazine|magazine=[[Dazed & Confused (magazine)|Dazed & Confused]]|first=Tim|last=Noakes|date=July 2010|issue=87|page=85|title=Shock to the System}} [[Miranda Sawyer]] of ''[[The Observer]]'' noted that although the metaphor in the video was obvious, the illustration was graphic and "some might say gratuitous". M.I.A. told Sawyer "It's just fake blood and ketchup and people are more offended by that more than the execution videos" referring to the clips of Sri Lankan troops shooting unarmed, blindfolded, naked men in the head that she tweeted beforehand, later telling French music magazine ''Mondomix'' "It’s amazing to me that is the state we're in today – people are more moved by something synthetic than something real. And as an artist that’s the decision you have to make – whether to be real or synthetic."{{Cite news|last=Bouard|first=Bertrand|title=M.I.A repousse les frontières (English translation: Activism without Borders)|url=http://www.rue89.com/mondomix/2010/07/11/mia-les-sri-lankais-sont-devastes-casses-158166|work=Mondomix|publisher=[[Rue 89]]|date=7 August 2010|accessdate=7 September 2010|language=French}} Similarly, Erin Thomson of ''[[Seattle Weekly]]'' concurred that the violence in the video was not gratuitous, noting that as an artist, M.I.A. "never pretended to be anything less than radical; she's never shied away from shock value. She comes from a world where persecution and terrorism are the norm, and from day one that's been the world she's tried to portray through her music."{{Cite web |url=http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/reverb/2010/04/mias_controversial_born_free_m.php# |title=Archived copy |access-date=29 August 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120709202032/http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/reverb/2010/04/mias_controversial_born_free_m.php# |archive-date=9 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} [[Xinhua]], the official news agency of the [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] and ''[[Global Times]]'', a paper owned by the [[Communist Party of China]] noted the removal of the film on American YouTube within a week of Born Free's release.{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/sci-edu/it/2010-04/527242.html |title=Global Times - M.I.A video restricted by YouTube |publisher=Globaltimes.cn |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2011-12-22}} M.I.A. condemned the Chinese Government's role in supporting and supplying arms to the Sri Lankan government during [[Eelam War IV]], stating that China's influence within the UN was preventing prosecutions of [[war crimes]] committed during the conflict. The coverage of the video in China was noted by Jemima Kiss of ''The Guardian'' to bring her work to the attention of more fans in the country; M.I.A. herself stated after the release she considered her child learn the Chinese language given the economic rise of the country.http://www.contactmusic.com/news/mia-considers-bringing-up-baby-in-china_1144182 ==See also== *[[Born Free (M.I.A. song)]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://vimeo.com/11219730 "Born Free"] music video on [[Vimeo]] *{{IMDb title|id=1661030|title=Born Free}} {{M.I.A.}} [[Category:Songs with music by M.I.A. (rapper)]] [[Category:2010 short films]] [[Category:Music videos directed by Romain Gavras]] [[Category:Music video controversies]] [[Category:Music videos]] [[Category:2010s musical films]] [[Category:2010 films]]

A '''Chastity House''' (or "Morality House")<ref>[http://www.parstimes.com/women/chastity_houses.html Iran: Proposal Debated For Solving Prostitution With 'Chastity Houses'] By Charles Recknagel/Azam Gorgin</ref> is a proposed but not ratified facility in [[Iran]] where couples can interact with each other to perform [[Nikah mut‘ah]].
In 2002, the main reason for reinstatement of Chastity Houses given to public was to prevent prostitution from spreading in the cities.<ref name="test">{{cite web|url=http://www.parstimes.com/women/chastity_houses.html |title=Iran: Proposal Debated For Solving Prostitution With 'Chastity Houses'|work=parstimes.com|accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref>
==Supporters of Chastity Houses== Several prominent conservative clerics have proposed that prostitutes be placed in government-run shelters for destitute women to be called "Chastity Houses," where male customers could briefly marry them under the Shia practice of Nikah mut‘ah. Proponents of the idea argue that it would "eradicate social corruption" by legitimizing sexual relations between the men and women.
A supporter of the plan, [[Ayatollah]] [[Kazem Mousavi-Bojnourdi|Mohammed Mousavi Bojnurdi]], said: "We face a real challenge with all these women on the street. Our society is in an emergency situation.” [[Hojatolislam]] Mohammed Taghi Fazel-Meibodi, a member of Qom Seminary, said the proposal is religiously legal. He said, "Our young people are troubled. There is poverty, unemployment, and more and more girls are escaping from their homes. In a society where there are sharp differences between rich and poor, rich men will use these poor girls for a quick thrill and to satisfy their impulses and lust."
==Opposition== Women's groups have been particularly outspoken about the idea of Chastity Houses. [[Shahrbanou Amani]], a female Iranian parliamentarian, called the idea of establishing Chastity House as "an insult and disrespectful to women." The Cultural Council for Women, a liberal Islamist women's group, said such houses would be a "deceitful and thinly disguised" form of prostitution.
==See also== * [[Prostitution in Iran]]
